editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Note, This ≈øhould follow the Letter to the Duke of Ormond, pag. 5. The Bi≈øhop of Winton's LETTER to the Lord Pre≈øident of the Council.
div.p: THE Obligation I have upon me as Vi≈øitor of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge in Oxon, occa≈øions this Addre≈øs: For I am inform'd that great endeavours are u≈øed with his Maje≈øty to recommend one Mr. Farmer, who is not at pre≈øent, nor ever was Fellow of the Colledge, to be Pre≈øident of it; which is directly contrary to the Statutes of the Founder, (as I am confident ≈øome who promote Mr. Farmer's intere≈øt, cannot be ignorant of:) And were there not many Per≈øons now actually Fellows, and ≈øeveral who have been (in particular the Bi≈øhop of Man, and Dr. Je≈øop) very eminent for Learning and Loyalty, and every way quallified according to the Statutes, I ≈øhould not pre≈øs your Lord≈øhip to lay the Concern of the Colledge (which hath upon all occa≈øions expre≈øt its Zeal and forwardne≈øs in Defence of the Crown, and (as I particularly know) in the great Affairs of the Succe≈ø≈øion) before his Maje≈øty; who, I hope, will leave them to their Rules as the Statutes, which have hitherto (excepting in the times of Rebellion) been concientiou≈øly ob≈øerved, and which will be the heighe≈øt ≈øatisfaction to the truly Loyal Univer≈øity, and promote his Maje≈øty's Service, which has always been the Endeavour of

div.head: A NARRATIVE OF THE Election of Dr Hough, Pre≈øident to St Mary Magdalen Colledge, OXON. 1687.
div.p:
THE Pre≈øident≈øhip of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, in the Univer≈øity of Oxon, being void by the death of Dr. Henry Clerk, late Pre≈øident of the ≈øame, the Vice-Pre≈øident gave notice to all the Fellows pre≈øent in the Chappel, on Thur≈øday the 31 of March, 1687; where it was unanimou≈øly agreed, to proceed to the Election of a Pre≈øident, on Wedne≈øday the 13 of April following, at Nine of the Clock in the Morning, in the Chappel: And in order thereto, the Vice-Pre≈øident cau≈øed a Citation to be fix'd on the Chappel-Door of the ≈øaid Colledge, ≈øignifying the Vacancy, Time, and Place of the Election; according to the direction of the Statutes. But before the day of Election, being credibly informed, that his Maje≈øty had been plea≈øed to grant his Letters Mandatory, in behalf of Mr. Anthony Farmer, they mo≈øt humbly repre≈øented to his Sacred Maje≈øty, in their Petition bearing Date April 9th, That the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer was uncapable, by their Statutes, of being Pre≈øident; and therefore did mo≈øt humbly pray his Maje≈øty to leave them to a Free Election, or recommend ≈øuch a Per≈øon to them, as was capable by their Statutes. Monday, April 11th, his Maje≈øty's Letters Mandatory, were delivered by the hands of Mr. Robert Chernock, Ma≈øter of Arts, and Fellow of the ≈øaid Colledge, directed to the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of Magdalen Colledge, in Oxon, requiring them forthwith to Elect the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer, and admit him Pre≈øident: Which Letter the Vice-Pre≈øident read in the Chappel of the ≈øaid Colledge, between the hours of four and five of the Clock in the ≈øame day, after Evening-Service, before the Fellows of the Colledge, there pre≈øent, and asked them, Whether they in Obedience to his Maje≈øty's Letters, would forthwith Elect and Admit Mr. Farmer Pre≈øident? Who all agreed, in con≈øideration to Mr. Farmer's not being Qualified, and the danger of Expul≈øion to any of the Fellows that ≈øhould be ab≈øent from the Election, and that the time of Election, according to the Citation, was ≈øo near, to defer their An≈øwer till Wedne≈øday following: Whereupon the Vice-Pre≈øident required all the Fellows to be pre≈øent in the Chappel the ≈øaid Wedne≈øday Morning at nine of the Clock. All the Fellows being then met, the Vice-Pre≈øident read the Statute De Electione Pre≈øidentis; and the Statute 5 Eliz. again≈øt corrupt Elections, was read al≈øo; after which the Vice-Pre≈øident read the King's Letter in behalf of Mr. Farmer, and
the ≈øecond time demanded an An≈øwer of the Fellows thereto. Their An≈øwer was to this effect: That having a Petition now lying before his Maje≈øty, they ought not to proceed to Election, till they had received his Maje≈øty's An≈øwer to the ≈øame: And thereupon they all agreed, (except Mr. Charnock) that the Election ≈øhould be deferred: which was accordingly done, until the next Morning nine of the Clock.

Thur≈øday, April 14th, at nine a Clock in the Morning, all the Fellows being met, the Vice-Pre≈øident told them, That the Election of a Pre≈øident had been deferred upon account of their Petition to his Maje≈øty, in An≈øwer to which, they had not then received his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure; that the next day was the utmo≈øt time they could defer the Election by the Statutes, and therefore it was nece≈ø≈øary they ≈øhould come to ≈øome Re≈øolution: he told them farther, That the King had commanded them to Elect Mr. Farmer, and asked their Sen≈øe therein: Which was unanimous (except Mr. Charnock) that the Election ≈øhould be deferred till the next morning eight of the Clock; and in order thereunto, the Sacrament to be admini≈øtred fir≈øt; and accordingly it was Adjourned.

Friday, April 15th, at eight a Clock in the Morning the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows being met, Dr. Tho. Smith and Capt. Bag≈øhaw, two of the Fellows, acquainted the re≈øt, from my Lord Pre≈øident of the Coun≈øel, That in An≈øwer to their Petition, his Maje≈øty having ≈øent his Letter to the Colledge, expected to be Obeyed. After which, the Vice-Pre≈øident read again the King's Letter to them, and asked, Whether in Obedience thereunto, they would Elect and Admit Mr. Farmer Pre≈øident? They an≈øwered, That they de≈øired they might proceed to an Election. Then the Vice-Pre≈øident having propo≈øed, Whether, having received his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure in An≈øwer to their Petition, they would make any further Addre≈øs? The Vice-Pre≈øident, Dr. Fairfax, Dr. Pud≈øey, and Dr. Tho. Smith, were for a ≈øecond Addre≈øs; but all the re≈øt declared immediately for proceeding to the Election.

Then the Vice-Pre≈øident propo≈øed, Whether they would go to an Election Viva voce, or by Scrutiny? The Vice-Pre≈øident, Mr. Thomp≈øon, and Mr. Charnock, were for proceeding to an Election Viva voce; all the re≈øt were for going to an Election by Scrutiny, except Dr. Tho. Smith, who was not for going to Election, until the King ≈øhould again be Petitioned.

This therefore being their Sen≈øe, That they ought to proceed to the Election of a Pre≈øident according to the Statutes, and this the la≈øt day limited for Election: In order thereunto, the holy Sacrament was ≈øolemnly taken by all, except Mr. Charnock. Then the Statute De Electione Prae≈øidentis, and 5 Eliz. again≈øt corrupt-Elections was read by the Vice-Pre≈øident. Every one took the Oath pre≈øcribed in the Statutes to be taken, in order to the Nomination of a Pre≈øident, (except Mr. Thomp≈øon and Mr. Charnock who refu≈øed it): And the 2 Senior Fellows were ≈øworn Scrutators in the Scrutiny of the whole Society: For the Nomination of a Pre≈øident, Mr. Hough and Mr. Maymard had each of them the major part of all the Voices; and were accordingly pronounced by the Seniour Scrutatour, Nominati in Ordine ad Electionem Prae≈øidentis: Then the thirteen Seniour Fellows being met to Elect one of the≈øe two Pre≈øident; and every one of them ≈øworn according to the Statute; eleven of them Elected Mr. Hough, who was accordingly pronounc'd Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, in Oxon. by the Seniour Scrutatour, in the pre≈øence of all the Fellows: and Mr. Maynard was appointed by the thirteen Seniour Fellows, to pre≈øent the ≈øaid Pre≈øident Elect, to the Vi≈øitour, in order to his Admi≈ø≈øion. After this, Mr. Thomp≈øon and Mr. Charnock declared, Viva voce for Mr. Farmer; according to his Maje≈øty's Letter.

Saturday, April 16th, Mr. Hough, Pre≈øident Elect, was pre≈øented to the Vi≈øitour by Mr. Maynard, who at the ≈øame time delivered to his Lord≈øhip an In≈øtrument under the Colledge Seal, containing the Proceedings of the Election; after a ≈øight whereof, Mr. Hough was Sworn and Admitted Pre≈øident by his Lord≈øhip, according to the Statutes.

Sunday, April 17th, Mr. Hough at his return to the Colledge, took the ≈øame Oath again before the Society, and afterwards, as Pre≈øident, took his Seat in the Chappel, at four a Clock Prayers in the Afternoon.

div.head: A Copy of the King's Mandate to the Fellows of Magdalen Colledge.
div.p: TRu≈øty and Well-beloved, We greet you well. Whereas we are well ≈øatisfied, of the Piety, Loyalty, and Learning of our Tru≈øty and Well-beloved Anthony Farmer, Ma≈øter of Arts, of that your Colledge of St. Mary Magdalen, We have thought fit hereby effectually to recommend him to you for the place of Pre≈øident of our ≈øaid Colledge, now void by the Death of Doctor Clark, late Pre≈øident thereof; willing and requiring you forthwith, upon receipt hereof, to Elect and Admit him the ≈øaid Anthony Farmer, into the ≈øaid place of Pre≈øident, with all ≈øingular the Rights and Priviledges, Emoluments and Advantages thereunto belonging, any Statute, Cu≈øtom, or Con≈øtitution to the contrary notwith≈øtanding; wherewith We are Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to Di≈øpence with in this behalf. And ≈øo, not doubting of your Compliance herein, We bid you Farewel.

closer.dateline: Given at Our Court at White-Hall, the Fifth Day of April, 1687, in the Third Year of Our Reign.

div.head: A Copy of Magdalen Colledge's Petition.
To the King's Mo≈øt Excellent MAJESTY. The Humble Petition of the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, in Oxon.
div.p: WE have been credibly Informed, That Mr. Anthony Farmer, who was not of our Foundation, has obtained Your Mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty's Recommendation to be Pre≈øident of Your Maje≈øty's Colledge, in the room of Dr. Henry Clark, Decea≈øed.

We therefore, with all Submi≈ø≈øion, as becomes Your mo≈øt Dutiful and Loyal Subjects, mo≈øt humbly Repre≈øent to Your Sacred Maje≈øty, That the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer is a Per≈øon in ≈øeveral re≈øpects Uncapable of that Character, according to our Founder's Statutes: And do mo≈øt earne≈øtly be≈øeech Your Maje≈øty, as Your Maje≈øty ≈øhall judge fitte≈øt in Your mo≈øt Princely Wi≈ødom, either to leave us to the di≈øcharge of our Duty, and Con≈øciences, according to Your Maje≈øty's late mo≈øt Gracious Toleration, and our Founder's Statutes; or to Recommend ≈øuch a Per≈øon who may be more Serviceable to Your Maje≈øty, and to this Your Maje≈øty's Colledge:

div.head: A Copy of the Lord Sunderland's Letter to the Fellows.
div.p: THe King being given to under≈øtand, That notwith≈øtanding his late Mandate, ≈øent to you for Electing Mr. Farmer to be Pre≈øident of your Colledge, you have made choice of another per≈øon; His Maje≈øty commands me to tell you, He is much ≈øurpri≈øed at the≈øe Proceedings, and expects you ≈øhould ≈øend me an Account of what pa≈ø≈øed on that Occa≈øion, and whether you did receive His Maje≈øty's ≈øaid Letters Mandate, before you cho≈øe Dr. Hough. I am,

closer.signed: Your Affectionate and Humble Servant, Sunderland.

div.head: The CASE of the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, in Oxon. in their late Election of a Pre≈øident.
div.p:
UPon the Notice of the Death of Dr. Henry Clark, Late Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge in Oxon; the Vice-Pre≈øident called a Meeting of the Fellows, in order to appoint a day for the Election of a new Pre≈øident. The 13th of April was the day prefix'd; with power to prorogue the Election to the 15th, as they ≈øhould ≈øee cau≈øe, beyond which time it was not in their power to defer the ≈øame. This being agreed, a Citation, or Praemonition was fix'd upon the Chappel-door of the Colledge, ≈øignifying the ≈øame; and ≈øummoning all the ab≈øent Fellows to repair home to the en≈øuing Election, as the Statute in that ca≈øe directs. After this, upon the 11th of April, they receiv'd His Maje≈øty's Letter in behalf of Mr. Farmer, requiring them to elect and admit him Pre≈øident: But he having never been Fellow of that Colledge, nor New-Colledge, in which are the only Per≈øons capable of being cho≈øen by the Statutes; and wanting likewi≈øe ≈øuch per≈øonal Qualifications as are required in the Character of a Pre≈øident, they did not imagine it was, or could be His Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure, that they ≈øhould act ≈øo directly contrary to the expre≈øs Words of their Statutes, to which they are ≈øtrictly and po≈øitively ≈øworn: But did humbly conceive they were bound in Duty to believe, that His Maje≈øty had been mi≈ø-informed in the Character and Capacity of Mr. Farmer. And therefore on the 15th of April, the la≈øt of tho≈øe days within which they were confin'd to fini≈øh the Election, they proceeded to a choice, and having fir≈øt received the Ble≈ø≈øed Euchari≈øt, and taken an Oath as the Founder enjoyns, to choo≈øe a Per≈øon ≈øo qualified, as is there ≈øpecified; they did elect the Reverend Mr. John Hough, Batchellor in Divinity, who is a Per≈øon every way qualified by the Satutes of the ≈øaid Colledge: And if it ≈øhall be objected that His Maje≈øty did in His Letter for Mr. Farmer, graciou≈øly di≈øpen≈øe with all the Statutes that rendered him uncapable of being elected; and that therefore they might have obeyed without breach of their Oaths: They humbly beg leave to repre≈øent, that there is an expre≈øs Clau≈øe in that Oath, which every Man takes when he is admitted Fellow of the Colledge; wherein he ≈øwears not to procure, accept, or make u≈øe of any Di≈øpen≈øation from his Oath, or any part thereof, by whom≈øoever
procured, or by what Authority ≈øoever granted. As to their former practice when they have elected in obedience to the King's Letter heretofore; it has been always in ≈øuch ca≈øes where the per≈øons recommended have been every way qualified for the Office by their Statutes; in which ca≈øes they always have been; and ever will be, ready to comply with His Maje≈øty's plea≈øure; it not being without un≈øpeakable regret, that they di≈øobey the lea≈øt of His Commands. They know how intirely their welfare depends upon the Countenance of their Prince; nor doth any thing more deeply affect and grieve their Souls, then when they find them≈øelves reduc'd to this unfortunate nece≈ø≈øity, of either di≈øobeying his Will, or violating their Con≈øciences by notorious Perjuries.

div.head: A Copy of a Letter to the Duke of Ormond, April 18th, 1687.
div.p: WE the Pre≈øident, and of Magdalen Colledge in Oxon, ≈øen≈øible of the Benefits and Honour we enjoy under your Grace's Patronage, and how much it imports us to have your Advice in all the Difficulties wherewith we are pre≈øs'd; having, as we fear, di≈øplea≈øed His Maje≈øty, in our Election of a Pre≈øident; do humbly beg leave to repre≈øent to your Grace, a true ≈øtate of our Ca≈øe, and hope you will plea≈øe to inform the King how uncapable we were to perform His Commands.

His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed on the Death of Dr. Henry Clark, Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, to Command us by His Letter, to elect, and admit, Mr. Anthony Farmer in that Office, a Per≈øon utterly uncapable of it by our Statutes, as we are ready to make appear in many particulars; and ≈øince we have taken a po≈øitive Oath of obedience to them, and that exclu≈øive to all Di≈øpen≈øations what≈øoever; we humbly conceive we could not obey that Command in favour of Mr. Farmer; unle≈øs he had brought tho≈øe Qualifications with him, which our Founder requires in the Per≈øon of the Pre≈øident; and being confined as to the time of Election, we have been forced to proceed to the choice of one, who has approved his Loyalty in the whole cour≈øe of his Life, and whom we think ≈øuitably qualified for the place. ‚Äî

May it therefore plea≈øe your Grace to interpo≈øe with His Mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty for us, that that we may not lye under the weight of His Di≈øplea≈øure, for not being in a capacity for obeying his Commands. We know him to be a Prince of eminent Ju≈øtice, and Integrity, and cannot think he will value any in≈øtance of Duty to him≈øelf, which manife≈øtly breaks in upon the obligation of our Con≈øciences. And your Grace's extraordinary unblemi≈øh'd Loyalty to the Crown; and that regard which we a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelves, our Mo≈øt Honoured Lord, and Chancellor, has to the Peace and Welfare of this Place, induceth us to pre≈øume your Grace will omit no endeavours to ≈øet before His Maje≈øty, the true Rea≈øon and Nece≈ø≈øity of our Proceedings. That God Almighty protect your Grace, ≈øhall be the daily Prayers of,

div.head: A Copy of the Citation to the Vice-Pre≈øident, and Fellows, for to appear at White-Hall, June the Sixth, 1687.
By His Maje≈øty's Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes, and for the Vi≈øitation of the Univer≈øities, and of all, and every Cathedral and Collegiate Churches, Colledges, &c.
div.p: COmplaint having been made unto Us, that the Vice-Pre≈øident, and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge in Oxon, have refu≈øed to comply with His Maje≈øty's Letters Mandatory, for electing and admitting Mr. Anthony Farmer Pre≈øident of the ≈øame Colledge, in the room of Dr. Clark decea≈øed, and that notwith≈øtanding his Maje≈øty's Leters they have elected Mr. John Hough Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Colledge: You and either of you are hereby requir'd to Cite & Summon the ≈øaid Vice-Pre≈øident & Fellows, requiring'em, or ≈øuch of the ≈øaid Fellows as they ≈øhall depute in their behalf, to appear before Us in the Council-chamber at White-Hall, upon Monday the Sixth of the next Month of June, at Four in the Afternoon, to an≈øwer to ≈øuch Matters as ≈øhall be objected again≈øt them, concerning the Premi≈øes, and of the due execution thereof: You are to certifie Us then and there.

closer.signed: To Thomas Atterbury, and Robert Eldows, Or to either of them.

div.head: The An≈øwer of the Vice-Pre≈øident, and other Fellows, of Magdalen-Colledge in Oxon, who were deputed by the ≈øaid Colledge, to the Que≈øtion propounded by the Right Honourable, and Right Reverend, the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs, Viz.
Why they did not obey His Maje≈øty's Letter, requiring them to Elect, and Admit Mr. Anthony Farmer Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Colledge?
div.p:
THE ≈øaid Vice-Pre≈øident, and other deputed Fellows an≈øwered and ≈øaid, That the ≈øaid Colledge of St. Mary Magdalen in Oxon is a Body Corporate, governed by Local Statutes, granted and confirmed to them by His Maje≈øty's Royal Predece≈ø≈øor, King Henry the 6th, for Him and His Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, under the Great Seal of England, which are al≈øo ≈øince confirmed by ≈øeveral other Letters Patents of others of His Maje≈øty's Royal Predece≈ø≈øors, under the Great Seal of England‚Äî That by the ≈øaid Statutes of the Colledge (to the ob≈øervation of which, each Fellow is ≈øworn) it is ordered that the Per≈øon elected Pre≈øident thereof, ≈øhall be a Man of good Life and Reputation, of approved Under≈øtanding, and good Temper, Di≈øcreet, Provident, and Circum≈øpect, both in Spiritual and Temporal Affairs. And at the time of Election of a Pre≈øident, the ≈øaid Fellows are bound by the ≈øaid Statutes, to take an Oath that they ≈øhall nominate none to that Office, but ≈øuch as are, or have been Fellows of the ≈øaid Colledge, or of New-Colledge in Oxon: or if they are not actually
Fellows at that time of Election; that they be ≈øuch as have left their Fellow≈øhips in their re≈øpective Colledges upon credible accounts. And when two qualified per≈øons ≈øhall be nominated at the time of Election, by the greater number of all the Fellows, to the ≈øaid Office of Pre≈øident; the thirteen Seniors al≈øo ≈øwear that they will Elect one of them, whom in their Con≈øciences they think mo≈øt proper and ≈øufficient, mo≈øt di≈øcreet, mo≈øt u≈øeful, and be≈øt qualified for the Place; without any regard to love, hatred, favour, or fear. And every Fellow when he is fir≈øt admitted into his Fellow≈øhip in the ≈øaid Colledge, ≈øwears that he will inviolably keep and ob≈øerve all the Statutes and Ordinances of the Colledge, and every thing therein contained, ≈øo far as does or may concern him, according to the plain, literal, and grammatical ≈øen≈øe and meaning thereof, and as much as in him lies will cau≈øe the ≈øame to be kept and ob≈øerved by others; and that he will not procure any Di≈øpen≈øation contrary to his afore≈øaid Oath, or any part thereof, nor contrary to the Statutes and Ordinances to which it relates, or any of them; nor will he endeavour that ≈øuch Di≈øpen≈øation ≈øhall be procured by any other, or others, publickly or privately, directly or indirectly. And if it ≈øhall happen that any Di≈øpen≈øation of this ≈øort, of what≈øoever Authority it ≈øhall be, whether in general or particular, or under what form of Words ≈øoever it be granted, that he will neither make u≈øe of it, nor in any ≈øort con≈øent thereunto. That upon Notice of the Death of Dr. Clark Late Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Colledge, the Vice-Pre≈øident called a Meeting of the ≈øaid Fellows, in order to the appointing a day for the Election of a new Pre≈øident, and the 13th of April was the time prefix'd, with power to prorogue the ≈øame as they ≈øhould ≈øee cau≈øe, till the 15th, beyond which time they could not ≈øtatutably defer their Election, and in pur≈øuance thereof a Citation, or Premonition, was fix'd upon the Chappel-door of the ≈øaid Colledge, ≈øignifying the ≈øame, and by which the ab≈øent Fellows were Summoned to repair home, as the Statute in the Ca≈øe requires. And the ≈øaid Vice-Pre≈øident, and other deputed Fellows farther ≈øay, that on the 11th of April afore≈øaid, they received His Maje≈øty's Letters Mandatory, to Elect and Admit the ≈øaid Mr. Anthony Farmer Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Colledge: But fora≈ømuch as the ≈øaid Vice-Pre≈øident, and Fellows, apprehended the right of Election to be in them, and believed His Maje≈øty never intended to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs them of their Rights: And fora≈ømuch as the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer had never been Fellow either of Magdalen, or New-Colledge in Oxon, and had not tho≈øe Qualifications which in, and by, the ≈øaid Statutes of the Colledge are required in the Character of a Pre≈øident, as they in their Con≈øciences did, or do verily believe; and in regard that they could not comply with His Maje≈øty's Letter, without the violation of their Oaths, and hazard of their legal Intere≈øt and Property, wherewith they are by their Statutes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and which by their Oaths they are bound to maintain, they repre≈øented the ≈øame by their humble Petition to His Maje≈øty. And having deferred their Election of a Pre≈øident to the la≈øt day limited by their Statutes, then they proceeded to Election, and having fir≈øt received the Euchari≈øt, and taken the ≈øaid Oaths, as the Statutes enjoyn, to choo≈øe a Per≈øon ≈øo qualified as is before expre≈ø≈øed, they did Elect the Reverend Mr. John Hough B. D. and one of the Fellows of their Colledge, a Per≈øon every way qualified to be Pre≈øident, who has been ≈øince confirmed by the Bi≈øhop of Winton their Vi≈øitor, as the Statutes of the ≈øaid Colledge direct.

And that they might not lye under His Maje≈øty's Di≈øplea≈øure by their Proceedings, they did on the 19th of April make an humble repre≈øentation thereof to His Maje≈øty, by his Grace the Duke of Ormond, Chancellor of the Univer≈øity of Oxon, ≈øetting forth their indi≈øpen≈øable obligations to ob≈øerve their Founder's Statutes.
All which Matters the Vice-Pre≈øident, and other deputed Fellows, do humbly offer to your Lord≈øhips, and pray to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with your Lord≈øhips favour.

div.head: The Fellows Rea≈øons why they Elected not Mr. Farmer, &c.
div.p: WHereas the Vice Pre≈øident, and other deputed Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge in Oxon, have in their An≈øwer to your Lord≈øhips, ≈øet forth, that by the Statutes of the ≈øaid Colledge, it is ordered, That the Per≈øon to be elected Pre≈øident thereof, ≈øhould be a man of good Life and Reputation, and of good Manners and Temper; and likewi≈øe, that Mr. Anthony Farmer hath not tho≈øe Qualifications which in and by the ≈øaid Statutes are requir'd in the Character of a Pre≈øident, as they in their Con≈øciences did and do verily believe. They humbly crave leave to repre≈øent to your Lord≈øhips ≈øome of tho≈øe Rea≈øons which induced them to ≈øuch belief, viz.

That Mr. Farmer did mi≈ø-behave him≈øelf in Trinity Colledge in Cambridge: That he received Admonition from the Ma≈øter of the Colledge, in order to his Expul≈øion; which remains in the Regi≈øter of the ≈øaid Colledge, under his own hand.
That having left Cambridge, he taught School at Chippenham in Wilt≈øhire, under a Nonconformi≈øt Mini≈øter, without Licen≈øe.

That in September 1683. the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer was entred in St. Mary Magdalen Hall in Oxon. where ≈øuch frequent Complaints were brought again≈øt him to the Principal, for his trouble≈øome humour and unquiet temper, that to pre≈øerve the Peace of the Society, he was de≈øired to leave the ≈øaid Hall.

That after his leaving Magdalen Hall, he was admitted into Magdalen Colledge, where di≈øcour≈øing about Religion, he declared, That there was no Prote≈øtant but would cut the Kings Throat: notwith≈øtanding which, at other times he declared to ≈øome of the Fellows of the ≈øaid Colledge, That what≈øoever he pretended, he was really a Member of the Church of England; and that he made an Intere≈øt with ≈øome Roman Catholicks, only to get Preferment by their means, and for that rea≈øon was willing to be thought of their Religion.

That at the very time when his Maje≈øty's Letter came to the Colledge in his behalf, the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer was at Abbington in very ill Company, where he continued drinking to exce≈øs two or three days and nights together; and among≈øt other Di≈øorders, was one of tho≈øe that then in the night time threw the Town-Stocks into the River: and that in general the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer hath had the unhappine≈øs to lie under an ill Fame, as to his Life and Conver≈øation, as by ≈øeveral Letters and Certificates, ready to be produced, will more largely appear.

div.head: Copies of Letters and Certificates delivered to the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs, June 27. 1687.

div.p: I. I Anthony Farmer, Batchelour of Arts, and Scholar of this Colledge, do confe≈øs, That I have behav'd my ≈øelf very unlike a Member of this Colledge, and even a Chri≈øtian, at the Dancing-School: for which I humbly ask Pardon, and do acknowledge before the Seniority, that I have de≈øervedly received of the Ma≈øter my fir≈øt Admonition in order to Expul≈øion.

postscript.p: This is a true Copy of Anth. Farmer's Admonition, atte≈øted by us who≈øe Names are hereunto under-written.

list.item: Humph Babington, Vice Magi≈øt. Deput.
John Hawkins, Vice Magi≈øt. Deput.
Benj. Pullsyn, Vice Magi≈øt. Deput.
John Laughton, Vice Magi≈øt. Deput.

div.p: II. THe≈øe are to certifie, That Mr. Anth. Farmer was U≈øher to Mr. Benj. Flower, a Nonconformi≈øt Preacher in the Town of Chippenham in the County of Wilts, for the ≈øpace of half a year or upwards, the ≈øaid Mr. Flower keeping School without Licen≈øe from the Bi≈øhop, and the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer continuing his U≈øher for the time mentioned, without any Licen≈øe al≈øo. Witne≈øs our hands,

list.item: Will. Lak ‚Ä¢ , Vicar.

div.p: III. MR. Anthony Farmer was entred of St. Mary Magdalen Hall in Oxford, Septem. 1. 1683. Where, after he had been ≈øome time, frequent Complaints were brought to me by ≈øome of the Ma≈øters, that he rai≈øed Quarrels and Differences among≈øt them; that he often occa≈øioned Di≈øturbances, and was of a trouble≈øome and unpeaceable humour. Whereupon, that Love and Friend≈øhip might be pre≈øerv'd and continu'd in the Society, as it u≈øed to be, I advi≈øed the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer to make tryal if he could live more ea≈øily and quietly in ≈øome other Hou≈øe. Accordingly he did voluntarily leave the Hall July the 13th 1685. and got him≈øelf admitted into Magdalen Colledge.

IV. I Do certifie, That Mr. William Bambrigg, Gentleman Commoner of Magdalen Hall, Oxon, did ≈øay, That Mr. Anthony Farmer, Ma≈øter of Arts, did intice him from his Studies in the Univer≈øity to go to London, where he the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer did attempt to draw the ≈øaid Mr. Bambrigg into ≈øeveral Debaucheries both at Taverns and Bawdy-hou≈øes. Witne≈øs my hand,

closer.signed: John Ryland, Mr. of Arts of Magd. Hall.

div.p: V. I Do certifie, That Mr. William Bambrigg. Gentleman Commoner of Magdalen Hall, did ≈øay, That Mr. Anthony Farmer, Ma≈øter of Arts of the ≈øaid Hall, did receive Money of him and other Gentlemen, publickly to expo≈øe unto them a Naked Woman; which he accordingly did. Witne≈øs my hand,

closer.signed: Richard Clerk, Mr. of Arts of Magd. Hall.

div.p: VI. I Am very willing to ju≈øtifie any thing I have formerly ≈øaid, relating to ≈øo ≈øerious a matter as this is you enquire after.

Mr. Farmer, one night in the Cloy≈øter, asked me why I did not get a Commi≈ø≈øion: I told him truly, I had not Friends to do it for me. He then asked me, what I would do for one: I told him, I would fight for my King, and what≈øoever he ≈øhould command me. He then ask'd me, if I would fight for the King's Religion: I told him, there would be no occa≈øion for that, nor would it ever be required of me. He as'd me of what Religion I was: I told him a Prote≈øtant. And then he ≈øaid, There was no Prote≈øtant but would cut the King's Throat; and that he ≈øhould lo≈øe Three thou≈øand pounds, for being of that Religion he intended to be of; which he ≈øaid was a Papi≈øt. This, to the be≈øt of my remembrance, is the full of what he ≈øaid. If I have omitted any thing, it is my care not to write more than I would hone≈øtly and ju≈øtly ≈øwear to. I am,

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt Obliged and mo≈øt Humble Servant, JOHN BRABOURN.

div.p: VII. IN or about January la≈øt, 1687. Mr. Anthony Farmer declared before us, That the Report of his being a Papi≈øt was fal≈øe; but that he was willing to be thought ≈øo, becau≈øe it might do him a kindne≈øs: That the rea≈øon of his acquaintance with Mr. Brent and Mr. Walker, was to get Preferment by their Intere≈øt: That he had not for≈øaken the Prote≈øtant Religion; adding, we ≈øhould call him Rogue, if ever he did: That he would not make any publick Declaration of this, but would declare it among≈øt Friends, when and where he plea≈øed.

list.item: Henry Dob≈øon.
Ja. Fayrer.
Tho. Goodwin.

div.p: VIII. I Do hereby certifie, That Robert Gardiner, Porter of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, did tell me, that Mr. Farmer did very often come into the Colledge late at night, ≈øo much in drink, that he could ≈øcarce go or ≈øpeak. Witne≈øs my hand, this 9th of June 1687.

IX. UPon Monday, April the third, Mr. Farmer came to the Lob≈øter in Abbington with Mr. Clerk, Mr. Gravener, and Mr. Jenny Jar, about eight in the morning, and ≈øtaid ≈øome time in the hou≈øe, and went from thence to the Tavern; return'd again about eleven at night, and ≈øat up till one in the morning: The next day they went to the Bu≈øh-Tavern and ≈øent for a quarter of lamb for their Supper, and there Mr. Farmer, Mr. Clerk, Mr. Gravener, and two Troopers and others, continued till pa≈øt eleven at night, and ≈øo return'd to the fore≈øaid place, and ≈øat up till pa≈øt three in the morning. This I do a≈ø≈øert, was the Company that the ≈øaid Mr. Anthony Farmer kept, and the≈øe were the un≈øea≈øonable Hours. In witne≈øs whereof, I am ready to ≈øwear, whenever a Subpaena ≈øhall be ≈øent to me.

X. MRs. Mortimer is ready to a≈ø≈øert, That when Mr. Anthony Farmer return'd to the Lob≈øter about eleven at night, he came much concern'd in Drink, and was for ki≈ø≈øing the ≈øaid Mrs. Mortimer, which, he being a ≈øtranger, ≈øhe permitted him to do; but in doing of it he the ≈øaid Mr. Anthony Farmer put his Tongue in her mouth, which was ≈øuch a rudene≈øs, that ≈øhe immediately went out of his company and would not come nigh him any more.

XI. BEing in company with William Hopkins of Abbington, the 12th of June la≈øt 1687. I heard him declare, That him≈øelf, with one Mr. Farmer of the Univer≈øity of Oxon, and ≈øome others, did in a Frolick, at an un≈øea≈øonable time of night, take away the Town-Stocks from the place where they con≈øtantly ≈øtood, and carried them in a Cart a con≈øiderable way, and threw them into a Pool commonly call'd Mad Hall's Pool. Witne≈øs my hand, the day and year above-written,

div.head: Some Clau≈øes of particular Statutes to which the Ca≈øe relates.
div.p: IN their Statutes concerning their Election of a Pre≈øident, his Character is thus de≈øcribed: That he mu≈øt be a man of good Reputation, and good Life, and circum≈øpect both in Spiritual and Temporal Affairs.
In the ≈øame Statutes the Oath which every Fellow is obliged to take, before he can give in the Nomination of a Pre≈øident, is this: Viz.

That he will name one or two of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, or of tho≈øe who have been Fellows there, or have left their places upon a legal and credible account: Or that he will name one or two of the Fellows of
St. Mary Winche≈øter Colledge, commonly called New-Colledge, in Oxon, or of tho≈øe who have been formerly Fellows there, and have left their places upon a credible account. After this, the thirteen Seniour Fellows ≈øwear, That out of the two thus nominated, they will, with all ≈øpeed, Elect one to exerci≈øe the Office of a Pre≈øident, whom in their Con≈øciences they think mo≈øt proper and ≈øufficient, mo≈øt di≈øcreet, mo≈øt u≈øeful, and be≈øt qualified for it, either without any regard to Love, Hatred, Favour, Fear, &c. as in the formentioned Statute is more largely expre≈ø≈øed.‚Äî

div.head: Part of the OATH which every Fellow takes when Admitted.
div.p: Item, I Do Swear that I will not procure any Di≈øpen≈øation contrary to my afore≈øaid Oath, or to any part thereof, nor contrary to the Statutes and Ordinances to which they relate, or any one of them; nor will I endeavour that ≈øuch Di≈øpen≈øations be procured by any other or others, publickly or privately, directly or indirectly: And if it ≈øhall, that any Di≈øpen≈øation of this ≈øort ≈øhall be procured, or freely granted, or obtained, of what Authority ≈øo ever it be, whether in general or particular, under what form of Words ≈øoever it be granted, I will neither make u≈øe of it, nor in any ≈øort con≈øent thereunto.

div.head: A Copy of Dr. Hough's Deprivation, by His Maje≈øty's Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs, &c.
div.p: WHereas it appears to us, that Mr. John Hough, B. D. hath been unduly Elected Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, in the Univer≈øity of Oxon, we have thought fit, upon mature con≈øideration thereof, That the ≈øaid Election be declared void, and the ≈øaid Mr. John-Hough be amoved from the ≈øaid Pre≈øident≈øhip; and accordingly we do hereby declare and decree, That the ≈øaid Election is void; and do amove the ≈øaid Mr. John-Hough from the place of Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Colledge.

div.head: A Copy of Dr. Aldworth's and Dr. Fairfax's Su≈øpen≈øion.
div.p: WHereas Charles Aldworth, Doctor of Laws, Vice-Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, Oxon, and the Deputys, Fellows of the ≈øame Hou≈øe, have been Convein'd before Us for their Contempt in not Obeying His Maje≈øty's Letters Mandatory, for Electing and Admitting Mr. Anthony Farmer Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Colledge; and the ≈øaid Dr. Aldworth and Deputies having been heard thereupon, We have thought fit to declare, pronounce, and decree, That the ≈øaid Dr. Aldworth ≈øhall for the ≈øaid Contempt be Su≈øpended from being Vice-Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Colledge: And that Henry Fairfax, Doctor of Divinity, one of the Fellows of the ≈øaid Colledge, ≈øhall for the ≈øaid Contempt be Su≈øpended from his Fellow≈øhip; and accordingly we do hereby Su≈øpend Dr. Charles Aldworth from being Vice-Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Colledge, and the ≈øaid Dr. Henry Fairfax from his Fellow≈øhip in the ≈øaid Colledge.

div.head: A Copy of the King's Inhibition to Magdalen Colledge.
div.p: TRu≈øty and Well-beloved, We Greet you well: Whereas We are informed, That a Sentence or Decree lately made by Our Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs, touching an Election in that our Colledge, hath not been Obeyed, Our Will and Plea≈øure is, No Elelection or Admi≈ø≈øion be made of any per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoever, into any Fellow≈øhip. Demy≈øhip, or other Place or Office in Our ≈øaid Colledge, till We ≈øhall ≈øignifie Our further Plea≈øure, any Statute, Cu≈øtom, or Con≈øtitution to the contrary notwith≈øtanding. And ≈øo, expecting Obedience herein, We bid you Farewel.

closer.dateline: Given at Our Court at Wind≈øor, the Eighteenth of July, 1687, in the Third Year of Our Reign.

div.head: A Copy of His Maje≈øty's Mandate for the Bi≈øhop of Oxon to be Pre≈øident.
div.p: TRu≈øty and Well-boleved, We Greet you well: Whereas the place of Pre≈øident of Our Colledge of St. Mary Magdalen, is now void, Our Will and Plea≈øure is, That We do hereby Authorize and Require you forthwith, upon receipt hereof, to Admit the Right Reverend Father in God Samuel Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon, into the ≈øaid place of Pre≈øident, to hold and enjoy the ≈øame, with all the Rights, Priviledges and Profits, Emoluments and Advantages thereunto belonging, any Statute or Statutes, Cu≈øtom or Con≈øtitution to the contrary, in any wi≈øe, notwith≈øtanding, wherewith We are Graciou≈øly plea≈øed, and do accordingly hereby Di≈øpen≈øe in his behalf: And ≈øo, expecting your ready Obedience herein, We bid you Farewel.

closer.dateline:
Given at Our Court at Wind≈øor,
Aug. 14th, 1687, in the Third Year of Our Reign.

div.head: A Copy of the Lord Sunderland's Letter to the Seniour Fellow of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, in the Univer≈øity of Oxon, or in his ab≈øence, to the Seniour Fellow re≈øiding there.
div.p: THe King having been plea≈øed by His Letters Mandatory, to require the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, to Admit the Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon, Pre≈øident of that Colledge; His Maje≈øty Commands me to let you know, That immediately upon the receipt hereof, he would have you A≈ø≈øemble the Fellows, and Communicate to them His Maje≈øty's ≈øaid Letters: And I am further Commanded to tell you, That His Maje≈øty expects a ready Obedience to be paid to His Plea≈øure herein. I de≈øire you would ≈øend me an Account of your Proceedings, as ≈øoon as you can, that I may acquaint His Maje≈øty with it. I am

div.head: A Copy of the Bi≈øhop of Oxon's Letter to the Seniour Fellow of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, in Oxon, or in his ab≈øence, to the Seniour Fellow re≈øiding there.
div.p: YOu will receive herewith His Maje≈øty's Mandate to Admit me Pre≈øident of your Colledge of St. Mary Magdalen, in Oxon, together with a Letter of my Lord Sunderland, pur≈øuant to His Maje≈øty's Commands. I am indi≈øpo≈øed, as I have been for ≈øome time, and not in a condition as yet to Travel; and therefore my reque≈øt to you is, That upon receipt of the King's Plea≈øure, you would do me the Favour to Admit me by Proxy, (i. e.) Either the next Seniour Fellow under your ≈øelf, re≈øident, or either of my Chaplains, Mr. William Wickins, or Mr. Thomas Collins, whom I depute in my ≈øtead, which is as valid in Law, as if I were pre≈øent my ≈øelf; and is the mo≈øt u≈øual and cu≈øtomary Practice. And by ≈øo doing, you will oblige

closer.signed: Your very Loving Friend and Brother, Samuel Oxon.

div.head: OXON. Sept. 4th, 1687.
The Lord Sunderland ≈øent an Order to the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, to attend the King at Chri≈øt-Church, at three in the Afternoon. They attended accordingly.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: WHat's your name, are you Dr. Pud≈øey?

sp.speaker: Dr. P.
sp.p: Yes, may it plea≈øe your Maje≈øty.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Did you receive my Letter?

sp.speaker: Dr. P.
sp.p: Yes Sir we did.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Then you have not dealt with me like Gentlemen, you have done very uncivilly by me and undutifully‚ÄîHere they all kneeled, and Dr. Pud≈øey offered a Petition, which His Maje≈øty refu≈øed to receive: And ≈øaid,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Ye have been a ≈øtubborn turbulent Colledge, I have known you to be ≈øo the≈øe 26 years: You have affronted me in this. Is this your Church of England Loyalty? One would wonder to find ≈øo many Church of England men in ≈øuch a bu≈øine≈øs. Go home and ≈øhew your ≈øelves good Members of the Church of England. Get you gone; know I am your King, I will be obey'd; and I command you to be gone: Go and admit the Bi≈øhop of Oxon Head, Principle; What d'ye call it of the Colledge ‚Äî? (One ≈øtood by ≈øaid Pre≈øident) I mean Pre≈øident of the Colledge. Let them that refu≈øe it look to it; they ≈øhall feel the weight of their Soveraign's Di≈øplea≈øure.

div.p: The Fellows going out of the Lodgings were call'd back.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: I hear you have admitted a Fellow of the Colledge, ≈øince you receiv'd my Inhibition; Is this true? Have you not admitted Mr. Holden Fellow?

sp.speaker: Dr. P.
sp.p: I think he was admitted Fellow: But we conceive‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mr. Cra.
sp.p:
May it plea≈øe Your Maje≈øty, there was no new Election or Admi≈ø≈øion, ≈øince
Your Maje≈øty's Inhibition; but only the Con≈øummation of a former Election. (They always Elect to one years Probation) then the Per≈øon Elected is received, or rejected for ever.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: The Con≈øummation of a former Election, 'twas downright Di≈øobedience, and 'tis a fre≈øh aggravation. Get you gone home, I ≈øay again; go, get you gone, and immediately repair to your Chappel, and Elect the Bi≈øhop of Oxon, or el≈øe you mu≈øt expect to feel the weight of my hand.‚Äî

div.p: The Felows offered again their Petition, on their Knees.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Get you gone, I will receive nothing from you, till you have obey'd me, and admitted the Bi≈øhop of Oxon.

div.p: Upon which they went immediately to their Chappel, Dr. Pud≈øey propo≈øing whether they would obey the King, and elect the Bi≈øhop of Oxon? They an≈øwered in their turns, They were as ready to obey His Maje≈øty in all things that lay in their power, as any of the re≈øt of His Subjects: But the Electing the Bi≈øhop of Oxon, being directly contrary to their Statutes, and the po≈øitive Oaths they had taken, they could not apprehend it in their power to obey Him in this Matter.

div.head: A Copy of the Petition offer'd at Oxford, Sept. 4th, 1687.
To the King's Most Excellent Maje≈øty, &c.
div.p: THat upon the 27th of August we receiv'd Your Maje≈øty's Letters Mandatory, Dated August 14th, requiring us to admit the Right Reverend Father in God Samuel Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon, to be our Pre≈øident; and di≈øpen≈øing with all Statutes and Con≈øtitutions to the contrary. It is an unexpre≈ø≈øible Affliction to us, to find our ≈øelves reduced to ≈øuch an extremity, that either we mu≈øt di≈øobey Your Maje≈øty's Royal Command, contrary to our own Inclinations, and that con≈øtant cour≈øe of Loyalty which we have ≈øhew'd in all in≈øtances hitherto upon all occa≈øions what≈øoever; or el≈øe break our Founder's Statutes, and deliberately perjure our ≈øelves.

For our Founder hath obliged us under Oath, when we came in Fellows, inviolably to ob≈øerve his Statutes, and one Clau≈øe therein injoyns us never to admit, or make u≈øe of Di≈øpen≈øation granted by any Authority what≈øoever, whereby we may be ab≈øolved from the ≈øame. In this Statute for the Election of a Pre≈øident, he commands us upon Oath to Elect ≈øuch a Per≈øon into the place of Pre≈øident, within 15 days after the vacancy, who either is, or has been Fellow of our own, or New-Colledge: Which we repre≈øented to Your Maje≈øty in our humble Petition, ≈øign'd April 9th, wherein we offered our ≈øelves ready to Elect any Per≈øon capable of the ≈øame, who Your Maje≈øty ≈øhould be plea≈øed to recommend, and having waited the utmo≈øt time limited by our Statutes, and receiv'd no An≈øwer to that effect, we did then according to the exigence of our Statutes (having fir≈øt taken the Holy Euchari≈øt, and our ≈øeveral Oaths to that purpo≈øe) nominate and Elect ≈øuch a Per≈øon, as we in our Con≈øciences did believe to be every way qualified for that Place: By which Act of ours, we have conveyed all that right to him, which our Founder hath intru≈øted us with; and it does not lie in our power to admit any other. Our Founder in another Statute obligeth us under the pain of Perjury, a dreadful Anathema, and eternal Damnation, not to ≈øuffer any of his Statutes to be altered, infringed, or di≈øpen≈øed with, and commands us under the ≈øame Sacred Obligations, not to execute any Orders or Decree what≈øoever, contrary or repugnant to the ≈øaid Statutes; by which ≈øaid Statutes, and Oaths, we are utterly incapacitated to admit the ≈øaid Reverend Father in God to be our Pre≈øident.

May it plea≈øe Your Sacred Maje≈øty, to give us leave to lay this our Ca≈øe, and our ≈øelves, withal ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, at Your Royal Feet, mo≈øt earne≈øtly be≈øeeching Your Sacred Maje≈øty, to extend to us Your humble Petitioners, that
Grace and Tenderne≈øs which Your Maje≈øty hath vouch≈øafed to all Your other Subjects; and not to believe us guilty of any ob≈øtinacy or undutifulne≈øs, Crimes which our Souls abhor; but to receive us into Your Maje≈øty's Grace and Favour, the greate≈øt temporal Ble≈ø≈øing which our Hearts can wi≈øh.

And Your humble Petitioners ≈øhall always (as in Duty bound) pray to Almighty God, to ble≈øs Your Maje≈øty with a long and happy Reign over us, and afterwards to receive You to an immortal Crown of Glory.

div.head: A Copy of the Addre≈øs which the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen gave to the Lord Pre≈øident of the Council, Sept. 6th, 1687; and which was delivered His Maje≈øty at Bath.
div.p: WE Your Maje≈øty's mo≈øt humble, and mo≈øt dutiful Subjects, the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge in Oxon, being deeply afflicted with the late ≈øen≈øe of Your Maje≈øty's heavy Di≈øplea≈øure; grounded, as we in all rea≈øon humbly pre≈øume, upon a mo≈øt unkind mi≈ørepre≈øentation of our Actions, in relation to an Election of a Pre≈øident, into Your Maje≈øty's ≈øaid Colledge: Do humbly beg leave to pro≈øtrate our ≈øelves at Your Royal Feet, offering all real Te≈øtimonies of Duty and Loyalty. And as we have never fail'd to evince both our Principles and Practices to be truly Loyal, in obedience to the Commands of Your Royal Brother, and Your Sacred Self, in matters of the like Nature: So what≈øoever way Your Maje≈øty ≈øhall be plea≈øed to try our readine≈øs to obey Your Royal Plea≈øure, in any in≈øtance that does not interfere with and violate our Con≈øciences, which Your Maje≈øty is ≈øtudious to pre≈øerve, we ≈øhall mo≈øt gladly and effectually comply therewith: A ≈øtubborn and a groundle≈øs re≈øi≈øtance of Your Royal Will and Plea≈øure, in the pre≈øent, and all other Ca≈øes, being that which our Souls eternally abhor, as becomes

closer.signed: Your Maje≈øty's most Loyal and most Obedient Subjects, &c.

div.head: A Copy of a Letter directed to Dr. Bayly Fellow of Magdalen Colledge, Oxon. ≈øuppo≈øed to be Writ by Mr. W‚Äî P‚Äî
div.p:
UPon an inquiry made of your pre≈øent Fellows of Magdalen Colledge, I am inform'd that you are a per≈øon eminent in that Learned Body, for your Temper, Prudence, and good Conduct in Affairs; and therefore very fit to be addre≈øs'd to by me, who do not ≈øend you this to trapan you, and your Brethren; but out of a pa≈ø≈øionate concern for your intere≈øt, to per≈øwade you, either to a compliance with His Maje≈øty's Letters Mandatory; or to think among your ≈øelves of ≈øome expedient to prevent the ruin of your Colledge, and your ≈øelves: And to offer it to His Maje≈øty's Royal Con≈øideration, that the Order for the Quo Warranto again≈øt the Colledge may be recall'd, before it be too late; for you cannot be ≈øen≈øible how highly His Maje≈øty is incens'd again≈øt you, neither can you give one in≈øtance whether ever that ≈øort of proceeding was judged again≈øt the Crown. Your Cau≈øe mo≈øt think it very hard; but you are not in Prudence to relye on the goodne≈øs of your Cau≈øe; but to do what the pre≈øent in≈øtant of Affairs will permit, and in patience to expect a Sea≈øon that will be more au≈øpicious to Per≈øons of your Character. Every
Mechanick knows the temper of His pre≈øent Maje≈øty, who never will receive a baffle in any thing that he heartily e≈øpou≈øeth, and that he doth this, your ≈øelves have had too late and manife≈øt an in≈øtance, to doubt of his zeal „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Affair.

Where there are ≈øo many Statutes to be ob≈øerved, 'tis impo≈ø≈øible but ≈øome mu≈øt be broken at one time or another; and I am informed by the Learned of the Law, that a failure in any one point, forfeits your Grant, and lays your Colledge open to the Royal di≈øpo≈øal.

I could give many other prudent Arguments, that might po≈ø≈øibly incline you to a ≈øpeedy endeavour of putting an end to your Troubles, almo≈øt, at any rate; but I ≈øhall ≈øugge≈øt this one thing to you, that your fatal overthrow would be a fair beginning of ≈øo much aimed at Reformation, fir≈øt of the Univer≈øity, then of the Church, and admini≈øter ≈øuch an opportunity to the Enemy, as may not perhaps occur in His Maje≈øty's Reign. I am

div.head: The An≈øwer to the aforementioned written Letter, Dated Oct. 3d. 1687.
div.p: THE inclo≈øed Paper is a Copy of a Letter, which by the charitable purpo≈øe of it, ≈øeems to be writ by you, who have been already ≈øo kind as to appear on our behalf, and are reported by all that know you, to imploy much of your time in doing good to Mankind, and u≈øing your Credit with His Maje≈øty, to undeceive him in any wrong impre≈ø≈øions given him of his con≈øcientious Subjects, and where his Ju≈øtice and Goodne≈øs have been thereby abu≈øed, to reconcile the Per≈øons injur'd to His Maje≈øty's Favour, and ≈øecure them by it from Oppre≈ø≈øion and Prejudice. In this confidence, I pre≈øume to make this application to you, de≈øiring your excu≈øe for not ≈øub≈øcribing it: For if you did write the Letter, you know to whom it was directed; and if you did not, I hope your Charity will induce you to make ≈øuch u≈øe of your light you have by it, into the Affairs of our Colledge, as to mediate for us with His Maje≈øty, to be re≈øtored to his good opinion, as the only thing which is de≈øired by us, who are zealous, above all earthly things, for his Felicity and Glory.

We are not con≈øcious of ever giving His Maje≈øty any ju≈øt Offence, as it will appear with you, when you ≈øhall have peru≈øed the enclo≈øed Papers; and have therefore no rea≈øon to fear the i≈ø≈øuing out of a Quo Warranto again≈øt us. And though you are plea≈øed to apprehend it, no in≈øtance can be given of a Judgment again≈øt the Crown, upon the proce≈øs of that Writ: The Learned in the Law tell me, there is nothing more common, and whereof many Ca≈øes are reported by Kellaway, from Page 128, to Page 152, of his Book of Reports: And I think I have heard of a Ca≈øe in Coke's ninth Report of the Abbe≈øs of Prata Marcella, which evinces the ≈øame; wherein al≈øo there is a recital of Judgment given again≈øt Roger Mortimer for the King, upon a Quo Warranto in Court of Eyre, revers'd for Errour in the King's-Bench. We hope though we have many Statutes, it will be found that we have not wilfully tran≈øgre≈øs'd any of them, for all our pre≈øent Troubles are derived to us from our adherence to them, and our fear to offend God, and blemi≈øh our Con≈øciences, by departing from them.

His Maje≈øty is intentionally righteous and ju≈øt in all his Proceedings, He will never knowingly invade any Man's Property, as He was ≈øolemnly plea≈øed to declare in his Excellent Speech made in Council, on the 6th of February, 1684, at his Acce≈ø≈øion to the Government; which is again repeated in His gracious Declaration for Liberty of Con≈øcience, of the 4th of April la≈øt pa≈øt. It is upon His Sacred inviolable, and Royal Word and Promi≈øe, we mu≈øt depend; not doubting but when His Maje≈øty ≈øhall be rightly inform'd of our Ca≈øe, in reference to both His Mandatory Letters to our Colledge, His Anger towards us will be totally extingui≈øhed.
Our compliance to the fir≈øt (which was Mr. Farmer's Election) would have involv'd us in the guilt of manife≈øt Perjury, and the wilful violation of our Statutes: And we are confident his Maie≈øty would never have granted the ≈øecond on the behalf of my Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon, if he had known we were then po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of a Pre≈øident duly Elected according to our Statutes, and confirmed by the Bi≈øhop of Winton, our Vi≈øitor (as the Statutes require); and if he is thereby inve≈øted with a Lay-Freehold under the protection of his Maje≈øties Laws, which we cannot undo or attempt to invade, without ≈øubjecting our ≈øelves to Suits at Law, and doing an apparent injury to the Pre≈øident, who doth not conceive him≈øelf to be affected with the Sentence of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øionets, (to which he was no Party) whereby his Place is declared void, without any Citations, Summons, or hearing of him.

I believe no in≈øtance can be given of a Quo Warranto brought again≈øt a Colledge or Hall in the Univer≈øities, from the fir≈øt foundation of them to this day, or any other Eccle≈øia≈øtical Corporation: for the Abu≈øes of ≈øome Con≈øtitutions or Franchi≈øes in them, and the Mi≈ødemeanours of particular Per≈øons, will not de≈øtroy a Colledge: And if the Corporation of a Colledge ≈øhould be di≈ø≈øolv'd, the Revenues thereof will return to the Founders Heirs, and not divolve to the Crown. And if our Colledge mu≈øt be the fir≈øt Example of that kind, we ≈øhall be better ju≈øtified by the ≈øtrict Ob≈øervation of our Statutes, (at lea≈øt to God and our own Con≈øciences) than we could have been by a voluntary and deliberate Breach of them.

It was Loyalty and Con≈øcience, that in the Reign of King Charles the Fir≈øt, made thirty four of our forty Fellows, and mo≈øt of the Scholars of our Foundation, rather quit their Places, and embrace Mi≈øery and Ruine, than to ≈øubmit to the Government of the U≈øurpers of the Crown. And in Monmouth's Rebellion, the ≈øame Inducements prevailed on us to rai≈øe a Company at our own charges, under the command of one of our Fellows, to engage again≈øt him. And we hope that the≈øe and many other the like in≈øtances, which may be given of the Loyalty and Zeal of our Society to the Royal Family, will be received as Evidences thereof, and that our good and gracious Soveraign will not exclude us from that Liberty of Con≈øcience, which he was pleas'd to extend to all his Subjects.

closer.signed: I am Your mo≈øt Affectionate Servant.

div.head: Some QUERIES ≈øent to the Fellows of Magdalen Colledge from Wind≈øor, September 15. 1687.
div.p: Fir≈øt, WHether, waving your Election of the Bi≈øhop of Oxon, you cannot, without violence to your Con≈øcience, ≈øignifie to his Maje≈øty, or the above Reverend Bi≈øhop, your willingne≈øs to admit the Lord Bi≈øhop Pre≈øident of your Colledge?

Secondly, Whether it be not more Intere≈øt to the Prote≈øtant Religion, to have a ≈øu≈øpected Popi≈øh Pre≈øident, than to have all the places of the Colledge refilled by the Kings ≈øole Authority with Popi≈øh Novices and Prie≈øts?

Thirdly, Whether you are not under a mi≈øtake, in thinking you ≈øhould render your ≈øelves more acceptable to the Prote≈øtant Nobility and Gentry, by your being turned out of your Fellow≈øhips by Inju≈øtice and Violence, as you conceive; or rather will not they be very cautious how they receive you into their Families, for fear of giving of Offence?

Fourthly, Whether his Maje≈øty, as Supream Vi≈øitor of the Univer≈øity, cannot place or di≈øplace there ad libitum; or whether you have a right notion of the Proceedings which have been practi≈øed again≈øt you? Whether you ≈øuppo≈øe that the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners proceeded again≈øt you as Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, or Vi≈øitors? Which Notion, I am ≈øure, will overthrow ≈øome bodies Plea and Exception again≈øt their Authority.

Fifthly, Whether you acted like men skilled in bu≈øine≈øs, when you refu≈øed Mr. Pen's Mediation, who you may be ≈øure had good Authority for what he did? You could not but know that man, and therefore mu≈øt needs be forearmed again≈øt any Wiles that could be offered to you. Whether an unanimous Sub≈øcription for an Expedient, (which indeed I think you ought not to refu≈øe in good manners, ≈øince the King was plea≈øed to propo≈øe it) pre≈øented to his Maje≈øty by Mr. Pen, or another Favourite, would prevent the de≈øtruction of the be≈øt Foundation in Europe.
La≈øtly, Whether you be not drawn beyond your Knowledge, by ≈øome hot-headed Advi≈øers, which never con≈øider the pre≈øent ≈øtate of his Maje≈øty's Court of Ju≈øtice?

div.head: An An≈øwer to ≈øeveral Queries to the Vice Pre≈øident and Fellows of Magdalen Colledge in Oxon, ≈øent from Wind≈øor, dated the 25th of September, 1687.
div.p:
To the Fir≈øt. WE cannot, without violence to our Con≈øciences, and deliberate Perjury, admit any per≈øon to be Pre≈øident of our Colledge, that is not elected thereunto, and qualified according to our Statutes; whereby the Bi≈øhop of Oxon is in no ≈øort capable; nor is there any Memorial in all our Regi≈øter of any admi≈ø≈øion of a Pre≈øident without Election, but of one Dr. Nicholas Bond, who≈øe ca≈øe was as followeth, (viz.) Upon the death of Dr. Lawrence Humphreys, about the 30th or 32th of Queen Elizabeth's Reign, the Queen recommended Dr. Bond (being a Fellow of our Colledge) to be Elected
Pre≈øident. Many of the Fellows inclin'd in their judgment to Elect one Smith (another of the Fellows) and at their meeting for Election, the Contention was ≈øo great, that they ro≈øe without Electing, and the Ob≈øtinacy continued till the place became laps'd: And there being no provi≈øion in our Statutes to direct us what to do in ≈øuch a Ca≈øe, the Queen, by her Letters Patents, Con≈øtituted the ≈øaid Dr. Bond to be Pre≈øident; and therein declared, That her Maje≈øty being inform'd that the Fellows had neglected to make Election of a Pre≈øident in due time, (as their Statutes required) and tho≈øe Statutes having made no provi≈øion for ≈øuch an Omi≈ø≈øion, She, out of her Princely care for the place, and indulgence for tho≈øe per≈øons who had been guilty of that neglect, did by advice of the Bi≈øhop of Winton, their Vi≈øitor, Con≈øtitute Dr. Bond their Pre≈øident; with prote≈øtation neverthele≈øs, that She did not thereby pretend to ≈øuper≈øede their Statutes, or invade their Right of Election, which was thereby inve≈øted in them, but took this cour≈øe as the only means left to ≈øupply their Defect of Election.

To the Second. We mu≈øt not make our ≈øelves guilty of deliberate Perjury, for any con≈øiderations what≈øoever, both in re≈øpect to our Con≈øciences, and that we may not by ≈øuch a Breach upon our Statutes, expo≈øe our Con≈øtitution to a Forfeiture, nor do Evil that Good may come on it.
To the Third. We conceive we ≈øhall be more acceptable to all good men, for acting hone≈øtly according to our Con≈øciences, than for voluntarily and unju≈øtly departing from our Right.

To the Fourth. We pretend not to make it a Que≈øtion, whether his Maje≈øty, by his Authority Royal as Supream Vi≈øitor, can grant a Commi≈ø≈øion for Vi≈øitation of any Colledge that has a Local Vi≈øitor by their Statutes, and are not Royal Foundations: But we are advi≈øed, that no Commi≈ø≈øion can be granted under the Great Seal to Vi≈øitors, to place and di≈ø-place Members of Colledges (who≈øe places are Freeholds) ad libitum, or di≈øcretum; but they mu≈øt proceed according to legal di≈øcretion, that is, by the Laws and Statutes of the Land, and the Local Statutes of the Colledge. And places concern'd for the Head≈øhips and Fellow≈øhips of Colledges, are Temporal Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and cannot be impeach'd by Summary Proceedings. One Dr. Thomas Loveney Pre≈øident of our Colledge, was deprived in Queen Elizabeth's time, by the Bi≈øhop of Winton, the Legal Vi≈øitor thereof E≈øtabli≈øh'd by Royal Authority, and he appeal'd to the Queen; but by the advice of all the Judges, it was held, that the Queen by her Authority, as Supream Vi≈øitor, could not meddle in it, but he mu≈øt bring „Äà1 span left blank„Äâ
We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, becau≈øe Deprivation was a Cau≈øe meerly temporal. The King has a great Authority Spiritual as well as Temporal; but no Commi≈ø≈øioners can be authorized by the Crown to proceed in any Commi≈ø≈øion under the Great Seal or otherwi≈øe, but according to Law; in Spiritual Cau≈øes by the Canon Law, in Temporal by the other Laws and Statutes of the Land. And wherein the proceedings in ≈øome Commi≈ø≈øions are directed to be ≈øummarie & de plano, &c.
„Äà1 span left blank„Äâ tho≈øe words are to be applied to ≈øhorten the Forms of Proce≈øs, and not for matter of Judgment: for Magna Charta provides for our Spiritual Liberties, as well as our Temporal.

div.head: AN Account of the VISITATION OF St Mary Magdalen Colledge in Oxon.
div.p: ON Oct. 19th, Mr. Atterbury the King's Me≈ø≈øenger, fix'd a Citation on the Colledge and Chappel-Doors, requiring the Pretended Pre≈øident and Fellows, and other Members of the Colledge to appear before the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Wright, and Mr. Barron Jenner, in the Chappel, at Nine of the Clock on Friday-morning, November 21≈øt.
On Thur≈øday the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners came to Oxon, attended with three Troops of Hor≈øe which Quarter there.

On Friday- Morning at Nine they went into the Chappel; the Pre≈øident and Fellows thinking they had de≈øign'd to fit in the Quire, made no preparation of Seats in the outward Chappel; upon which their Lord≈øhips adjourned to the Hall, where their Commi≈ø≈øion was then read, which in general was the ≈øame with the former: The≈øe three being added to the other Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, and particularly impowred to vi≈øit Magdalen Colledge only.
This done, the Names of the Pre≈øident and Fellows were called over, Dr. Hough being fir≈øt called. All in Town appeared, (except Dr. Fairfax) and excu≈øes were made for the ab≈øent.

Then a Speech was made by the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, and in it his Lord≈øhip was Severe again≈øt Di≈øloyalty and Di≈øobedience. He urg'd that the Church of England taught an unconditionate and unlimited Obedience; He ≈øpake of the Kings Gracious Promi≈øes to Arch-Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, &c. which had de≈øerved thanks on bended Knees, notwith≈øtanding the Oxon Rea≈øons to the contrary which they knew be≈øt who was the Authour thereof. He told them that it could not be expected, but that the King would give all incouragement to tho≈øe of his own Religion, which could be done without ≈øeverity and cruelty which His Maje≈øty abhorr'd, and without injuring the Church of England, which was at pre≈øent e≈øtabli≈øh'd by Law: He told them that this Corporation as well as others were the Creatures of the Crown; and that it was in≈øolence in their Local Statutes to ≈øpurn again≈øt their Maker.

That their Di≈øtempers had brought this Vi≈øitation upon them, the Con≈øequences of which might be ill to the Church and Univer≈øities: That however they might e≈øcape in this World, the≈øe Sins were to be accounted for above their other Sins in the next. He Exhorted them by the Bowels of Chri≈øt to con≈øider the≈øe things: He told them, that the Eyes of the World were upon them, and they ought to take care that their Practices might not influence their deluded admirers. In ≈øhort, the whole de≈øign of the Speech ≈øeem'd to be promi≈øes and threats, to aime at the inducing them to a complyance.

p.hi: The Court was then Adjourned till Two in the Afternoon.

div.head: In the Afternoon were called over the Names of the Demoys, Chaplins, Clerks, Chori≈øters, and Colledge Servants. The Pre≈øident then interpos'd, de≈øiring leave to ≈øpeak before they proceeded any further; which being granted, he told their Lord≈øhips: That

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: THE time betwixt your Citation and Appearance was ≈øo ≈øhort; that the Society had not time to advi≈øe with the Council how to behave them≈øelves on this Occa≈øion: Therefore de≈øired of your Lord≈øhips a Copy of the Commi≈ø≈øion, and time to con≈øider of it.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øhop Ch.
sp.p: 'Tis upon Record, you may have it above.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Is it the ≈øame the other Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners had?

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Yes for the mo≈øt part it is.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Then my Lord, I do a≈ø≈øure you (and will make Oath if you plea≈øe) that I have often endeavoured to get a Copy of it, and could not procure it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you not heard it Read, or will you hear it again?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I am not capable of making a Judgment of it my ≈øelf, but it is po≈ø≈øible there may be Errours and Defects in't, ≈øuch as the Society may make u≈øe of to their own advantage, and I am confident it is neither his Maje≈øties intention nor your Lord≈øhips we ≈øhould be debar'd from it.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Dr. Hough, will you ≈øubmit to this Vi≈øitation?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lords, I do declare here in the name of my ≈øelf, and the greater part of the Fellows; that we ≈øubmit to the Vi≈øitation, as far as it is con≈øi≈øtent with the Laws of the Land, and the Statutes of the Colledge, and no further. I de≈øire your Lord≈øhips that it may be Recorded.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You cannot imagine that we Act contrary to the Laws of the Land, and as to the Statutes the King has di≈øpen≈øed with them: Do you think we come here to act again≈øt Laws.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: It does not become me (my Lords) to ≈øay ≈øo, but I'le be plain with your Lord≈øhips; I find that your Commi≈ø≈øion gives you Authority to change and alter the Statutes, and make new ones as you think fit: Now my Lords we have an Oath, not only to ob≈øerve the≈øe Statutes (laying his hand on the Book) but to admit of no new ones, or alterations in the≈øe; This mu≈øt be my behaviour here, I mu≈øt admit of no alteration from it, and by the Grace of God never will.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Do you ob≈øerve all the≈øe Statutes?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I hope we do.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: You have a Statute there for Ma≈øs, why don't you read Ma≈øs?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lord, the matter of this Oath is unlawful; and in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, no man is oblig'd to ob≈øerve an Oath: Be≈øides, the Statute is taken away by the Laws of the Land.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: By what Law?

sp.speaker: Dr. Stafford.
sp.p: By that which obliges to ≈øay Common-Prayer.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: What, the Act of Uniformity? I have often con≈øidered it, and don't remember one word of Ma≈øs in it.

sp.speaker: Dr. Staff.
sp.p: But that obliges us to u≈øe the Liturgy of the Church of England, in all Collegiate Churches and Chappels: And, I hope, my Lords, you do not imagine that we can ≈øay Common-Prayer and Ma≈øs together.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Do you allow that Act of Parliament can free you from the obligation of a Statute.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
I do not ≈øay, but that his Maje≈øty may alter our Statutes, nor do I know but a Parliament may do the ≈øame; I di≈øpute not their Power: onely this, my Lord, I ≈øay, that I who already have taken an Oath to ob≈øerve the≈øe Statutes as they now ≈øtand, and am ≈øworn not to admit of any change or alteration by any Authority what≈øoever, [And then turning to the Oath where they were to ob≈øerve the≈øe Statutes and no other, according to the Literal and Grammatical ≈øence, &c. and reading it to their Lord≈øhips.] can
obey none: But then tho≈øe who come after ≈øuch Limitations and Re≈øtrictions are made, are not oblig'd to ob≈øerve 'em; and that, my Lords, is our Ca≈øe, as to the Statutes of the Ma≈øs.

div.p: Then the Decree of the 22d of June was read, declaring the Pre≈øident's Election Null and Void.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Did you know of this Commi≈ø≈øion, &c.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I have heard of it.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Why then did you not obey it?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I was never Cited before their Lord≈øhips, nor was either heard by them in Per≈øon or Proxy; and I think I am the onely in≈øtance that is extant, of any man that was ever depriv'd of a Free-hold, wherein he was legally inve≈øted, and of which he was quietly po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd, without being Summon'd or Heard.

div.p: Here mention was made of Dr. Fairfax's Su≈øpen≈øion.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lord, He is ab≈øent, and if your Lord≈øhips give me leave, I have ≈øomewhat to ≈øay on his account; your Lord≈øhips may plea≈øe to ob≈øerve in that Decree, that the rea≈øon given, why Dr. Fairfax was Su≈øpended from his Fellow≈øhip, was, becau≈øe he had not obeyed his Maje≈øty's Command, in not Electing Mr. Anthony Farmer Pre≈øident of the Colledge: Now the Charge of Immorality given in again≈øt Mr. Farmer by the Colledge; Delegates was made out, and their Lord≈øhips fully ≈øatisfied in it, on the 29th of July ‚ñ™ notwith≈øtanding which, this Decree for Su≈øpen≈øion of Dr. Fairfax, was fix'd on the Colledge-Gates, August 2d.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: The King hath for the mo≈øt part recommended to the Pre≈øident≈øhip of this Colledge.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I am the Twentieth Pre≈øident, and onely four of that number hath been recommended by the Kings and Queens of England, whereof three were every way qualified for that Office.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Who were tho≈øe?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lord, there was one in the time of Edward the Sixth one in Queen Elizabeth's, and two in the late King's Reign.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Was there never a one in King Charles the Fir≈øt's Reign?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Not that we know of.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: What think you of Dr. Oliver?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: It doth not appear to us, my Lord, that he ever had a Mandate.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: But it appears to us, and that I will bring you one to ≈øwear, that he had a Mandate.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: The truth is, we have lo≈øt the Regi≈øter of Dr. Oliver's Election and Admi≈ø≈øion; the Regi≈øter betwixt the Year 1640, or thereabouts, and 60 being taken away by tho≈øe who were turn'd out of the Colledge at that time; but I believe, my Lord, we are able to prove that he was Elected and Admitted according to Statute.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Was Dr. Clark a Statutable Per≈øon?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Do not the Statutes require that he ≈øhould be in Orders? was he in Orders?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lord, the Statutes onely require that he ≈øhould be Doctor of Divinity, Phy≈øick, Law, or Ma≈øter of Arts: There is indeed one Statute which ≈øays, The Pre≈øident or Seniour Fellow ≈øhould Read Prayers upon ≈øuch certain Days; from whence we conclude, that the Founder ≈øuppos'd we might have a Pre≈øident that might not be in Orders; and in ≈øuch a ca≈øe he takes care that the Seniour Fellow ≈øhould do his Duty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Char.
sp.p: My Lord, will you be plea≈øed to ask Dr. Hough, whether Dr. Clark was Married or not?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: No, Sir, he was a Widdower.

div.p:
Then a Petition was read from the Society to his Maje≈øty, ≈øigned the 9th of April, and pre≈øented the 10th to the Earl of Sunderland, by the hands of Dr. Thomas Smith and Captain Bag≈øhaw, wherein 'twas ≈øet forth, that having heard that his Maje≈øty would recommend
Mr. Farmer to them a per≈øon uncapable; they did humbly be≈øeech him either to leave them to a free Election, or to recommend a qualified per≈øon.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Was this the Petition? An≈øwer, Yes.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Why then did you not ≈øtay for his Maje≈øty's An≈øwer?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lord, We did till the very la≈øt day wherein we are limited to fini≈øh the Election; and my Lord Sunderland returned, in the King's name, this An≈øwer, That his Maje≈øty expected to be obeyed. Now, my Lord, we did no longer defer the Election, becau≈øe our Statutes enjoyn us within ≈øuch a time, and we ≈øtaid to the utmo≈øt. Nor could we chu≈øe the per≈øon his Maje≈øty did recommend, knowing him to be ≈øo unfit, as we afterward made him appear to be. The Society was therefore to proceed to the Election of another per≈øon, and did agree on ≈øuch as you ≈øee.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: A Mandate always implies an Inhibition.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot conceive that,

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: But I can; and if you que≈øtion it, here's the King's Councel ready to argue it.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lord, Whil≈øt the per≈øon his Maje≈øty recommends appears duly qualified for the place, it ≈øeems indeed to imply that we ≈øhould not proceed to the Election of another; but when he is known to be utterly uncapable, it ≈øeems to be the ≈øame as if there were no Letter at all.

div.p: Some other things and que≈øtions le≈øs material were put, and then the Court was Adjourned to Saturday the 22d, nine in the morning, to the common Room, the Hall being (as they ≈øaid) too publick and incommodious.

div.head: SATURDAY, October 22d, 1687.
div.p: As ≈øoon as their Lord≈øhips met in the common Room, and the Society before them, the fir≈øt word was Withdraw; and after a little time, the Pre≈øident was called in alone.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: DO you ≈øubmit to the Decree of the Commi≈ø≈øioners, whereby the Election is declared Null?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: As to that Decree of the Lords above, it is a Nullity in its ≈øelf from the beginning to the end, as it relates to me, I never having been Cited, nor having ever appeared before them, either in Per≈øon or by Proxy: Be≈øides, my Cau≈øe it ≈øelf was never before them; their Lord≈øhips never inquiring or asking one que≈øton concerning the Legality or Statutablene≈øs of my Election: for which rea≈øons (as I am informed) that Decree was of no Validity again≈øt me, according to methods in the Civil Law: But if it were, I am po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a Free-hold, according to the Laws of England, and the Statutes of the Society, having been Elected as Unanimou≈øly, and with as much Formality as any one of my Predice≈ø≈øors Pre≈øidents of this Colledge, and afterwards Admitted by the Lord Bi≈øhop of VVinton, our Vi≈øitor, as the Statutes of the Colledge require; and therefore I can't ≈øubmit to that Sentence, becau≈øe I think I cannot be depriv'd of my Free-hold, but by cour≈øe of Law at VVe≈øtmin≈øter-hall, or by being ≈øome ways incapacitated by the Founder's Statutes.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Will you deliver up the Keys of the Pre≈øident's Office and Lodgings, to the u≈øe of that Per≈øon whom the King has appointed your Pre≈øident, as the Statutes require.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I will immediately do it, if that appear.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Turn to that part of the Pre≈øident's Oath where he promi≈øeth to ≈øubmit quietly if he ≈øhall be Expelled, either for his on Fault vel ob aliam Cau≈øam.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lord, That Statute onely concerns me, if I am Expelled for any fault committed by me.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, to be ≈øhort, here is no cau≈øe at all.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: I ask you again, Will you deliver up the Keys to the Pre≈øident whom his Maje≈øty hath appointed?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: There neither is nor can be a Pre≈øident ≈øo long as I live, and obey the Statutes of the Colledge; and therefore I do not think fit to give up my Right, the Keys and Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: We may demand them of you as Vi≈øitors.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lords, we never deliver up the Keys to the Bi≈øhop of Winton; and we own no greater Vi≈øitatorial Power than his, he hath the King's Authority. 'Tis by Verttue of a Royal Charter that we live together, and enjoy the benefit of this Place, that impower'd our Founder to give us a Rule, and obliged us by Oath to act ≈øuitable unto it: and the Bi≈øhop of Winton is hereby con≈øtituted to be our Vi≈øitor; and all this we own from the King's Authority. The Bi≈øhop of Winton is our ordinary Vi≈øitor; the King (I pre≈øume) our extraordinary. But your Lord≈øhips know it hath been controver≈øed, Whether the King can vi≈øit a private Colledge or not? The Authority of the Pre≈øident is made by delivering up the Statute-Book, and Keys; and therefore I look upon them as an e≈ø≈øential Badge of my Office.
But I humbly beg that I may ask your Lord≈øhips one Que≈øtion.
Your Lord≈øhip is plea≈øed to demand of me to give up the≈øe things: Does your Lord≈øhip own my Right? For if not, which is it your Lord≈øhips would have me give up?

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: No, we look upon you as an Intruder.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: If I am an Intruder, the Bi≈øhop of Winton made me one, and I thank God for it.
