My Lords, the time we have been allowed for this appearance, has been very ≈øhort, but one day betwixt it and the Citation: We are men ignorant in the Laws, and I mu≈øt confe≈øs it of my ≈øelf in particular, that I have endeavoured to give your Lord≈øhips a plain and ≈øatisfactory Reply to ≈øuch Que≈øtions as your Lord≈øhips have been plea≈øed to put to me. It is very probable that through ignorance and inadvertency I may expre≈øs my ≈øelf unwarily: If ≈øo I be≈øeech your Lord≈øhip let no advantage be taken of it, my intention has been always to expre≈øs my ≈øelf with all imaginable Duty to the King, and Re≈øpects to your Lord≈øhips. If I have done otherwi≈øe, I be≈øeech your Lord≈øhips Candor in a favourable Interpretation of what I ≈øaid, that nothing may be taken ami≈øs, where all was dutifully intended. And now my Lords, thus far have I appear'd before you as Judges; I now addre≈øs to you as Men of Honour, and Gentlemen, I be≈øeech you to repre≈øent me as dutiful to His Maje≈øty to the la≈øt Degree, as I always will be, ≈øo far as my Con≈øcience permits me, to the la≈øt moment of my Life; and when I am di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øt here, I hope your Lord≈øhips will interceed, that I may no longer lie under His Maje≈øty's Di≈øplea≈øure, or be frown'd upon by my Prince, which is the greate≈øt Affliction can befall me.

div.p: Upon this the Pre≈øident was ordered to withdraw, and after a little time, he and the Fellows were called in again. Then the Bi≈øhop repeated this Que≈øtion.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Dr. Hough, Will you deliver up the Keys, and quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Lodgings, to the Per≈øon whom His Maje≈øty has appointed Pre≈øident? To which no An≈øwer was return'd. The Bi≈øhop repeated a Second time.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My Lords, I have neither ≈øeen nor heard any thing to induce me to it.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Dr. Hough, Will you deliver up the Keys and quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Lodgings, to the Per≈øon whom His Maje≈øty has appointed Pre≈øident‚ñ™
Whereupon the King's Proctor ≈øtood up and accu≈øed Dr. Hough of Countumacy; then the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter admoni≈øh'd him in the≈øe Words; three times.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Dr. Hough, I admoni≈øh you to depart peaceably out of the Lodgings, and to Act no longer as Pre≈øident, or pretended Pre≈øident of this Colledge.

div.p: Which being ≈øo done, they ≈øtruck his Name out of the Book, and admoni≈øh'd the Fellows, and others of the Society, that they ≈øhould no longer ≈øubmit to his Authority.

div.head: SATURDAY, October 22d, 1687. OXON.
Dr. Fairfax's CASE before the Commi≈ø≈øioners.
div.p: AT the fir≈øt Se≈ø≈øions Doctor Fairfax purpo≈øely ab≈øented him≈øelf; but Mr. Atterbury making Affidavit he was in Town, and that he advi≈øed him to appear, the Doctor accordingly did ≈øo the next day. The Doctor being called in alone, and the Doors immediately ≈øhut, he begg'd of their Lord≈øhips ≈øome Company might be let in; becau≈øe, as all had ob≈øerved the Bi≈øhop in his Speech, at the opening their Commi≈ø≈øion, promi≈øed to tran≈øact every thing in the face of the World. The Bi≈øhop complained of the Crowd. The Doctor then de≈øired to fetch in but Two or Three, at length but One, and him at the Door, viz. The Colledge Steward, a Publick Notary.

sp.speaker: Bar. Jen.
sp.p: You mu≈øt not think to pre≈øcribe to the Court.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: What's the Cau≈øe of your Contempt, in not appearing at either Se≈ø≈øions ye≈øterday?

sp.speaker: Dr. Fair.
sp.p: No Contempt my Lord, but for the≈øe en≈øuing Rea≈øons.

Fir≈øt, I thought my Su≈øpen≈øion above had ea≈øed me of that trouble. The Doctor tendring a Copy of it, which was read by the Commi≈ø≈øioners. The Doctor in≈øi≈øted very much on the Rea≈øon ‚Ä¢ their Lord≈øhips, at White-Hall, gave for his Su≈øpen≈øion. (viz) For not obeying His Maje≈øty, in Electing Mr. Farmer, he tendring a Copy of Articles made good again≈øt him; and yet their Lord≈øhips ordered his Su≈øpen≈øion to be fix'd on the Colledge-Gates five days after that famous Hearing. Second Rea≈øon for his Non-appearance, that upon the fir≈øt day of the en≈øuing Term, he intended to meet the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, at his Court of King's-Bench, for relief again≈øt the Sentence, his Fellow≈øhip being a Free-hold, witne≈øs Coveny's Ca≈øe.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: You will find but little Favour there.

sp.speaker: Dr. Fair.
sp.p: My Lord, in Courts of Judicature, I only expect Ju≈øtice, and turning to the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice. I have, my ≈øelf, ≈øaid he, been above four years in all the Courts of We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, and found excellent Ju≈øtice, and I will ≈øee how it is now.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Ju≈øt.
sp.p: You ≈øhall have Ju≈øtice.

sp.speaker: Dr. Fair.
sp.p: But your Lord≈øhip may ≈øave me the labour of two Journeys, and my Charges, by improving your Lord≈øhip's de≈øerved Intere≈øt with my Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners there, and get them now to take off my Su≈øpen≈øion: It is ill travelling at this time of year; and be≈øides I am not rich.

sp.speaker: Bar. Jen.
sp.p: To ≈øue in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall requires a Pur≈øe.

sp.speaker: Dr. Fair.
sp.p: My Lord, I did not ≈øay I was poor.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Ju≈øt.
sp.p: You mu≈øt make your Supplication, and Submi≈ø≈øion, to the King.

sp.speaker: Dr. Fair.
sp.p: My Lord, they tell me that this bu≈øine≈øs lyes in your Lord≈øhip's Court, and only there, (be≈øides the trouble I am otherwi≈øe to give your Lord≈øhip: What a noi≈øe will the cau≈øe make that Dr. Fairfax is ≈øu≈øpended for this very rea≈øon, (viz.) not obeying the King in Electing Anthony Farmer, ≈øuch a Virtuo≈øo, and under correction, your Lord≈øhips are obliged to take off my Su≈øpen≈øion, to take off the ≈øhame from that Body, who≈øe number by a Common Adjunct you your ≈øelves have lately increas'd.

sp.speaker: Bar. Jen.
sp.p: We mu≈øt not endure the≈øe Reflections on the Court.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh.
sp.p: But will you ≈øubmit to this Vi≈øitation?

div.p:
Then Dr. Fairfax read a Paper ≈øub≈øcribed by him, Dated October the 22d, in the≈øe words: My Lords, I have been Summon'd, and appeared in this Cau≈øe before the Lords Eccle≈øia≈øtical at White-Hall, with whom your Lord≈øhips are
now joyn'd in Commi≈ø≈øion; and then gave in my An≈øwer: I have nothing to add to it, and find no rea≈øon to retract it.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh.
sp.p: Will you admit of the Bi≈øhop of Oxford?

sp.speaker: Dr. Fairf.
sp.p: I am Su≈øpended.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh.
sp.p: Have you done no Collegiate-Act ≈øince your Su≈øpen≈øion?

sp.speaker: Dr. Fairf.
sp.p: My Lord, I have gone into the Hall, and laid in my Chamber: I did not think their Lord≈øhips, when they ≈øu≈øpended me, ever intended that I ≈øhould not eat, drink, or ≈øleep.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh.
sp.p: If your Su≈øpen≈øion was off, would you ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxford:

sp.speaker: Dr. Fairf.
sp.p: Truly, my Lord, I cannot do it.

p.hi: Then all the Fellows were called into Court.

div.p: The Pre≈øident being withdrawn, the Bi≈øhop put the Que≈øtion to all the Fellows, (viz.) Whether they would a≈ø≈øi≈øt at the Admi≈ø≈øion of the Bi≈øhop of Oxford to be in≈øtalled Pre≈øident by vertue of the King's Mandate? To which was an≈øwered by all the Fellows, to this effect: (except Dr. Pud≈øey, and Dr. Tho. Smith, who an≈øwered doubtfully, and Chernock that he would a≈ø≈øi≈øt) That they were under Oaths to the contrary, and therefore could not do it.
Then all were ordered to withdraw; and Dr. Pud≈øey being called in alone, they asked him concerning the Manner and Form of In≈øtalling a Pre≈øident; which he in≈øtructed them in.

p.hi: The Court Adjourn'd till Two in the Afternoon.

div.p: AS ≈øoon as they met, a Letter from the E. of Sunderland to Dr. Pud≈øey, was read, dated the 2d of Augu≈øt, ≈øignifying‚ñ™ That the Society, in an≈øwer to his Maje≈øty's Letter commanding them to admit the Bi≈øhop of Oxford, agreed unanimou≈øly in this An≈øwer, That the place was full. Their Lord≈øhips were plea≈øed to ask the Fellows ≈øingly, Whether that was their An≈øwer? And as many as were there, owned that it was.

During this Examination, the Pre≈øident came into Court, and having waited until it was ended, and their Lord≈øhips at a Pau≈øe, he made his Application to them: My Lords, if your Lord≈øhips plea≈øe to give me leave, I would gladly ≈øpeak a few words. They were all plea≈øed to put off their Hats, and ≈øay he might. Whereupon he ≈øaid, My Lords, you were plea≈øed this Morning, in pur≈øuance to a Decree of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners at London, to deprive me of my place of Pre≈øident of this Colledge, and to ≈øtrike my Name out of the Buttery-book: I do hereby prote≈øt again≈øt all your Proceedings, and again≈øt all that you have done, or hereafter ≈øhall do in prejudice of me and my Right, as Illegal, Unju≈øt, and Null: and therefore I appeal to my Soveraign Lord the King in his Courts of Ju≈øtice. Upon which the Strangers and young Scholars in the Room gave a H∆≤M; which ≈øo much incen≈øed their Lord≈øhips, that notwith≈øtanding all the Prote≈øtations the Pre≈øident and Fellows could make, the Pre≈øident in particular offering to purge him≈øelf by Oath, that he was no way acce≈ø≈øary to or abetting of it, and declared that he was heartily a≈øhamed and troubled at it; yet the L.C.J. was not to be pacified, but charging it upon the Pre≈øident, bound him in a Bond of 1000 l. and Security to the like value, to make his Appearance at the Kings-Bench-Bar, the 12th of Nov.

After this, was read the An≈øwer the Fellows returned to his Maje≈øty upon his Command to them upon the 4th of Sept. to elect the Bi≈øhop of Oxford: the An≈øwer was under the hand of a publick Notary, ≈øub≈øcribed by all the Fellows then pre≈øent, except Mr. Chernock. The Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter was plea≈øed to charge the Fellows of Unmannerline≈øs, for ≈øending ≈øuch an An≈øwer to their Prince after ≈øuch a manner.
So they Adjourned till Tue≈øday the 25th, at Eight in the Morning.

div.head: TUESDAY the 25th of October.
div.p: WHen the Court met, Dr. Stafford offered a Paper in an≈øwer to what was objected on Friday, that a Mandate implied an Inhibition; which their Lord≈øhips having peru≈øed, would not ≈øuffer to be read publickly, but askt the Fellows whether they would ≈øign it, bidding them to do it at their peril.

Then the Fellows had leave to withdraw into the Hall, and not being ≈øatisfied that it was nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øign a Plea, which their Lord≈øhips refu≈øed to have argued, they returned the Paper into the Court, ≈øub≈øcribed only by Dr. Fairfax and Dr. Stafford. The latter, after ≈øome debate, de≈øired to withdraw, but Dr. Fairfax ≈øtood to it.

div.head: A Copy of Dr. Stafford's and Dr. Fairfax's PLEA.

body.head: To the Right Reverend and Right Honourable his Maje≈øty's Commi≈ø≈øioners for the Vi≈øiting of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge in Oxford.
body.p:
ON Friday la≈øt, in the afternoon, you ≈øeem'd to in≈øi≈øt very much on this, (viz.) That his Maje≈øty in commanding the Fellows of the ≈øaid Colledge to Elect Mr. Farmer Pre≈øident, did thereby inhibit them to Elect any other Per≈øon what≈øoever; which has not yet been made appear to be Law, either out of the Books of Civil, Canon, or Common Law. Neither is it agreeable to Rea≈øon, that a Command to Elect a Per≈øon uncapable, ≈øhould include in it an Obligation not to Elect a Per≈øon capable, that being a kind of contradiction in ternimis. Yet this being granted, it cannot in the lea≈øt affect the ≈øaid Fellows, or invalidate their Election of Dr. Hough, notwith≈øtanding his Maje≈øties Mandate in behalf of Mr. Farmer, who being incapable of the place, the Fellows cannot be ≈øaid to be guilty of any Di≈øobedience or Di≈øloyalty, in proceeding to the Election of another Per≈øon who was quallified according to Statute, being forced to make an Election. For they are oblig'd by the Statutes of their Colledge, (when call'd together) to Elect a Pre≈øident, or any Officer under pain of perpetual Expul≈øion from the Colledge, to meet and make an Election; which puni≈øhment they incur ip≈øo facto, who either refu≈øe to meet when ≈øo call'd, or being met, to nominate or elect a per≈øon into the Office void, as appears by the Statutes of the ≈øaid Colledge: Titulo de numero Scholdrium & electione Prae≈øidentis. Now, according to the Founders direction in the ≈øaid Statute, on the 15th of April la≈øt, the Fellows were call'd together by the Vice-Pre≈øident to Elect a Pre≈øident in the place of Dr. Clark deceas'd, and the Oath de≈øired to be taken before the Election was admini≈øtred by the Vice-Pre≈øident to them, whereby they are oblig'd to nominate and elect a per≈øon that either is or has been Fellow of Magdalen Colledge or New Colledge in Oxon; which Oath when the Fellows had taken, it was not in their power to elect Mr. Farmer; and yet they were then oblig'd to make an Election under pain of perpetual a motion from the Colledge, as appears by the forecited Statute. And it cannot be imagin'd that his mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty did expect that the Fellows ≈øhould be either perjur'd, or forfeit their Right to their Fellow≈øhips, rather than di≈øobey his Command; his Maje≈øty having mo≈øt graciou≈øly declar'd, that Con≈øcience ought not to be forced, and that none of his Subjects ≈øhould be mole≈øted in the enjoyment of their Rights and
Priviledges, &c. Now that our Proceedings at the Election cannot lay any imputation of our Di≈øobedience or Di≈øloyalty upon us, will thus be made appear: Either we had the power to Elect a Pre≈øident, or we had not; if we had not, to what end or purpo≈øe did his Maje≈øty command us to elect one? if we had, our power was either re≈øtrain'd to Per≈øons ≈øo and ≈øo quallified, or we were at liberty to chu≈øe whom we pleas'd; but we could not do the latter, as appears by our Statutes: and therefore we could not elect Mr. Farmer, being not inve≈øted with any power to elect a Per≈øon unquallified. And if we had ≈øo done, our Election would have been null and void in it ≈øelf, and the Per≈øon elected liable to be turn'd out by our Vi≈øitor.

As for the Decree of his Maje≈øty's Commi≈ø≈øioners (in pur≈øuance of which your Lord≈øhips have admoni≈øh'd Doctor Hough to receed from the place of Pre≈øident, and quietly to re≈øign the Keys of his Office, and have ≈øtruck his Name out of the Colledge-Book) we humbly conceive it to be null and void in it ≈øelf, to all intents and purpo≈øes, Dr. Hough being thereby depriv'd of Freehold for life, (of which he was duly and legally po≈ø≈øe≈øt) without ever being call'd to defend his Right, or any Mi≈ødemeanour objected again≈øt him. Wherefore we humbly beg leave of your Lord≈øhips, that Dr. Hough may be permitted to defend his Right and Title to the Pre≈øident≈øhip at Common Law, before any other Per≈øon is put in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the place.

div.p: After this Mr. Wiggins, Chaplain to the Bi≈øhop of Oxford, was called in, who delivered a Paper impowering him as Proxy, to be In≈øtalled Pre≈øident for his Lord; which being read, together with the King's Mandate for the Bi≈øhop of Oxon; which Letters is as follows. The que≈øtion was put to two or three of the Seniours, Whether they would a≈ø≈øi≈øt at this In≈øtalment? which they refu≈øing, the Court Adjourned to the Chappel, where the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter put Mr. Wiggins into the Pre≈øident's Stall, where he took the Oath which the Statutes enjoyn the Pre≈øident at his Admi≈ø≈øion, and the Oaths of Alegiance and Supremacy; the latter of which he was ordered to take upon his Knees, which he accordingly did. Then their Lord≈øhips conducted him to the Door of the Pre≈øident's Lodgings, where knocking three times, and the Door not being opened, they returned to the Common Room, and Commi≈ø≈øion'd Atterbury and a Tip≈øtaff, to fetch a Smith to force it open, which was done, their Lord≈øhips being pre≈øent all this while. None of the Fellows, except Mr. Chernock, a≈ø≈øi≈øting, or being ≈øo much as pre≈øent at either of the≈øe performances. Then the Commi≈ø≈øioners being returned to the Common Room, Dr. Fairfax de≈øired leave, at their lei≈øures, to ≈øpeak; which was granted.

sp.speaker: Dr. Fairf.
sp.p: My Lords, your Lord≈øhips have been doing of what I can by no means con≈øent to.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: You are big to be delivered of your own de≈øtruction. Will you ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon, as now in≈øtalled, Pre≈øident, by vertue of the King's Mandate?

sp.speaker: Dr. Fairf.
sp.p: I will not; I cannot; becau≈øe we have a Statutable and legal Pre≈øident already.

div.p: Then the ≈øame Que≈øtion was put to the Society, which being a bu≈øine≈øs of moment, they de≈øired time till the Afternoon to con≈øider it.

Then the Court Adjourned till Three a Clock; at which time the An≈øwer was given in by the Society, (except Dr. Fairfax, who had given his in the Morning) That whereas His Maje≈øty hath been plea≈øed by his Royal Authority to cau≈øe the Right Reverend Father in God, Samuel Bi≈øhop of Oxon, to be In≈øtalled Pre≈øident; we who≈øe Names are hereunto Sub≈øcribed, do ≈øubmit, as far
as is lawful and agreeable to the Statutes of the Colledge, and no way prejudicial to the Right and Title of Dr. Hough.

This An≈øwer was accepted, except the la≈øt Clau≈øe; which the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, and Barron Jenner, declared, as Judges, to be in≈øignificant, ≈øince nothing they could do, could any way invallidate Dr. Hough's Title, but left them ≈øtill at liberty to be Witne≈ø≈øes for him, or any other way be ≈øerviceable to him in the recovery of his Right. Upon this a≈ø≈øulrance, the Society was prevailed with to cave out the la≈øt Clau≈øe.

Then all were commanded to withdraw: And Dr. Fairfax being called in, the Bi≈øhop asked him what he meant by his Paper abovementioned, Date October the 22d; and whether he did ≈øubmit to the Authority of the Court?

sp.speaker: Dr. Fairf.
sp.p: As I have denied it above, ≈øo I do here.

div.p: Then the Court was opened; and the Doctor complained before them all, that he was twice Clo≈ø≈øeted, and being asked, Whether he would obey the Court and Bi≈øhop of Oxon? he plainly denied both. Upon which the Buttery-Book was called for, and the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter commanded his Name to bo ≈øtruck out: And this Sentance pa≈ø≈øed, Viz.

Fora≈ømuch as you have denied the Authority of the Court, and refu≈øed to obey the Bi≈øhop of Oxon, whom the King hath made your Pre≈øident; and taken Commons after your Su≈øpen≈øion: We declare your place void, and command you quietly to depart the Colledge within fourteen days.

sp.speaker: Dr. Fairf.
sp.p: My Lords, all the huge Calamities that have befallen me, are of the ≈øole account of a Religious and Con≈øciencious Ob≈øervation of our Pious Founder's Statutes; who≈øe Bread I have eaten almo≈øt this Thirty Years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No Speeches: be≈øides, if you have any Papers, in≈øtead of reading them, leave them in the Court.

div.p: Then, with much ado, the Doctor prevailed with them to let him read his Prote≈øtation, which he left in the Court.‚Äî

body.p: I Henry Fairfax, Fellow of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge, do under my former An≈øwer heretofore made, and to the intent it may appear that I have not con≈øented, nor agreed to any thing done again≈øt me, and to my prejudice, I prote≈øt that your Sentence given here again≈øt me, is Lex nulla, and ≈øo far as it ≈øhall appear to be aliqua; I do ≈øay it is iniqua & inju≈øta, and that therefore I do from it, as iniqua & inju≈øta, appeal to our Soveraign Lord the King, in his Courts of Ju≈øtice, as the Laws, Statutes, and Ordinances of the Land will permit in that behalf. Sub≈øcribed

div.p: This Prote≈øtation was over-ruled, and a Copy of the Sentence denyed, though mo≈øt earne≈øtly de≈øired at the in≈øtance of Dr. Hedges, and Mr. Vice-Chancellor, two days after.

At the clo≈øe of the Se≈ø≈øions, their Lord≈øhips declared, that they were very well ≈øatisfied with the An≈øwer the Soiety had given them; and though before they had laid a Libel to their charge, yet, that Night, they declared, they had met with nothing from them but Civility, and that they ≈øhould receive the ≈øame from them; that they had ≈øhewn them≈øelves men of excellent tempers this day and before; and that they would repre≈øent it faithfully above to their advantage, and that if it any way lay in their power to ≈øerve them, they ≈øhould be very ready to do it.
Then they Adjourned till Wedne≈øday-Morning, ordering them to bring in their An≈øwer to the following Que≈øtions:

list.item: I. What Gifts and Provi≈øions have you for Entertainment of Strangers?
II. What is the Value of it?
III. How is it applied?
IV. And where is the Place of Entertainment?

div.head: WEDNESDAY, Octob. 26, 1687.
div.p: IN the Morning they made it apper to their Lord≈øhips very ≈øatisfactorily, that they were obliged to give in Charity-money, 2 l. 3 s. 4 d. and that be≈øides that, they gave communibs annis, almo≈øt 100 l. as appeared by a Paper they then delivered in. Upon this their Lord≈øhips were plea≈øed to expatiate upon their generous Bounty and Liberality, ≈øaying the Complement of this Account was groundle≈øs, and that it would induce the King to a better belief of them in all other matters.

Then a Petition of Dr. Rogers, late Organi≈øt, was given in, de≈øiring to be re≈øtored, which was read; but ≈øeveral Mi≈ødemeanours being proved again≈øt him, it was thrown out; and he advi≈øed to re≈øt ≈øatisfied with 30 pound per annum, which the Colledge had be≈øtowed on him when they turn'd him out of his Place.

div.head: THURSDAY, Octob. 27, 1687.
div.p: THis Morning they received a Li≈øt of Lea≈øes, &c. which had been renew'd two years la≈øt pa≈øt: Mr. Chernock, the new Convert, asked their Lord≈øhips, Whether tho≈øe Lea≈øes ≈øtood good, which had been Sealed ≈øince Dr. Hough's Election? The Lord Chief Ju≈øtice an≈øwer'd, Yes; for Corporations always ≈øtick by their Seals. Then their Lord≈øhips peru≈øed the Colledge Regi≈øters, and finding nothing in them to object again≈øt, they were returned, and the Court Adjourned till the Afternoon: At which time their Lord≈øhips told them, That having received no Expre≈øs from above, as they expected, they would Adjourn till Friday at Eight in the Morning.

div.head: FRIDAY, Octob. 28, 1687.
div.p: THe Commi≈ø≈øioners being Seated, all were commanded to withdraw: then only the Fellows were called in, and the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter ≈øaid they had repre≈øented them fairly to the King; but that His Maje≈øty expected ≈øome farther Submi≈ø≈øiion, which they advi≈øed them to make, by acknowledging their contempt to His Sacred Maje≈øty in Per≈øon, and to His Letters; and that they ≈øhould promi≈øe to behave them≈øelves Loyal for the future; and that they ≈øhould ≈øome ways own the proceedings and legality of the Court, and implore His Maje≈øty's Pardon, and lay them≈øelves at His Feet.

The Fellows making a little pau≈øe, the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter told them, they might Word it them≈øelves; or if they thought fit Mr. Tucker ≈øhould a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in a Form. Then all the Fellows withdrew into the Hall, and drew up the following An≈øwer:

body.p: WE have endeavoured in all our Actions, to expre≈øs our duty in all humility to His Maje≈øty, and being con≈øcious to our ≈øelves, that in the whole Conduct of the bu≈øine≈øs before your Lord≈øhips, we have done nothing, but what our Oaths and Statutes indi≈øpen≈øably oblige us to, we cannot make any Declaration, whereby we acknowledge that we have done any thing ami≈øs, having acted according to the Principles of Loyalty, and Obedience, ≈øo far as we could, without doing violence to our Con≈øciences, or prejudice to our Rights, (one of which we humbly conceive the Electing a Pre≈øident to be) from which we are ≈øworn upon no account what≈øoever to depart. We therefore humbly beg your Lord≈øhips to repre≈øent this favourably, with our utmost Duty to His Maje≈øty, whom God grant long, and happily to Reign.

div.p: Upon their Lord≈øhips peru≈øing of the an≈øwer, they expre≈ø≈øed their di≈ølike of it, ≈øaying, it did not come up to the Addre≈øs ≈øent to his Maje≈øty at Bath which was read; to this it was replyed, that they hoped their behaviour ≈øince, had been every way an≈øwerable to what they had therein promi≈øed. Then their Lord≈øhips ≈øaid, that it did not come up to what they delivered in on Tue≈øday.

sp.speaker: Dr. Bayly.
sp.p: My Lords, we have acted conformable to our ≈øelves, and truly my Lords, I cannot po≈ø≈øibly confe≈øs any crime.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh.
sp.p: We do not expect of you to confe≈øs any Capital crime, only to make ≈øome acknowlegment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fulham.
sp.p: My Lord, We were ordered to addre≈øs our ≈øelves, as having acted in contempt of his Maje≈øties Authority, which my Lord, I look upon as ≈øo great a crime; that on no account I would be guilty of it. My Lord, we have indeavoured to obey His Maje≈øty to the utmo≈øt of our power, and ≈øeeing your Lord≈øhips were plea≈øed to accept our an≈øwer on Tue≈øday, I humbly conceive your Lord≈øhips Honour is engaged, that nothing further be required of us.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh.
sp.p: You are a very forward ≈øpeaker, and abound in your own ≈øen≈øe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fulh.
sp.p: My Lord, I hope Your Lord≈øhip will give me leave to ≈øpeak, when our Fortunes are ≈øo con≈øiderably at ≈øtake‚Äî

div.p: Then Dr. Bayly de≈øired of their Lord≈øhips, to give him leave to explain, what he meant by the word Submit in his An≈øwer on Tue≈øday; becau≈øe (≈øaith he) I hear your Lord≈øhips under≈øtood more then was meant, and lea≈øt your Lord≈øhips ≈øhould go away under a mi≈øtake, by the word Submit in the former An≈øwer, I did not intend any future Obedience to the Bi≈øhop of Oxford; but meant it in reference to the Kings Authority, ina≈ømuch as I did not oppo≈øe or re≈øi≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Oxford's in≈øtalment.

Upon this, a fre≈øh que≈øtion was put to the Fellows, whether they would obey the Bi≈øhop of Oxford as their Pre≈øident in licitus & hone≈øtis; to which all except one or two an≈øwered, they could not obey the Bi≈øhop of Oxford as their Pre≈øident.
Then Mr. Fulham was particularly asked the que≈øtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fulham.
sp.p: Dr. Hough being duely Elected and admitted Pre≈øident doth thereby obtain a right, which I am not ≈øatisfied he hath any way forfeited, and therefore can obey no per≈øon as Pre≈øident.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Will you obey the Bi≈øhop of Oxford as in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fulh.
sp.p: I cannot, becau≈øe the Bi≈øhop hath not lawful Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

div.p: Then he was asked wherein?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fulh.
sp.p: He hath not Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in due form of Law, nor by proper Officers: I am informed that the proper Officers to give po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a Freehold, is the Sheriff with a Po≈ø≈øe Comitatus.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray, who's the be≈øt Lawyer you or I? Your Oxford Law is no better then your Oxford Divinity: If you have a mind to a Po≈ø≈øe Comitatus, you may have one ≈øoon enough‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mr. Fulh.
sp.p: My Lords, I intended nothing but re≈øpect to your Lord≈øhips, and have indeavoured to ≈øpeak and behave my ≈øelf with due reverence, and I hope your Lord≈øhips will put a favourable con≈øtruction on what I ≈øaid‚Äî

div.p: Then all were commanded to withdraw, and the Buttery-Book was called for, and after that, Mr. Fulham was ≈øent for in; and by the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter ≈øu≈øpended as followeth‚Äî

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. of Ch.
sp.p: Mr. George Fulham, We have thought fit to Su≈øpend you from the Proffits of your Fellow≈øhip during His Maje≈øties Plea≈øure, for your contempt and opprobrious Language‚Äî

div.p: Then they Adjourned till Wedne≈øday, the 16th. of November, Ordering the ab≈øent Fellows to be ≈øent for home again≈øt that time. So they immediately went for London.

div.head: WEDNESDAY, November the 16th. 1687, at Nine in the Morning.
div.p: THE Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners being ≈øate: The fir≈øt thing they did, ≈øent for the Buttery-Book; then called for Mr. Joyner and Mr. Allibone, and enterd them Actual Fellows. The former in the Room of Dr. Fairfax whom they had Expelled; The latter in place of Mr. Ludford lately decea≈øed: All Oaths being di≈øpenced with be≈øides that of a Fellow. That done the Fellows being called, and Rea≈øons given in for tho≈øe that were ab≈øent. The Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter ≈øpoke a Speech to this effect.

Gentlemen, Your many Contempts, and wilful Di≈øobedience, have occa≈øioned this Vi≈øitation, which will end at last in your ruin. This Society of yours has been long exerci≈øed in the Methods of Quarrelling; has always been troubled with Factious Spirits, and te≈øty Mutineers, ever ≈øince the Re≈øtoration of the late King: You have encourag'd Quarrels among your ≈øelves; Quarrels between your ≈øelves and Pre≈øident; Quarrels, at length, between your ≈øelves and Vi≈øitor. For I have often heard your late Vi≈øitor complain, that this Society was ever ≈øtocked with an unquiet and turbulent Generation. By the≈øe ≈øteps from quarelling with the Pre≈øident, and Vi≈øitor, you have at last advanced to the highest pitch of In≈øolence, to quarrel with your Prince, and affront His Sacred Maje≈øty. I endeavour'd before, at the opening Our Commi≈ø≈øion, to make you ≈øen≈øible of the Scandal that your Di≈øobedience will bring upon your Religion; how much you ≈øtain and di≈øhonour your liberal and ingenious Education, in this Society.

You cannot but know His Maje≈øty is your Supream Ordinary. You cannot but have read in Bracton, who was twenty years Lord Chief Ju≈øtice under King Henry the third: Nemo Pre≈øumat de factis ejus di≈øquirere ne dum contra factum ejus venire: All Di≈øobedience imploys Pride: For no man can di≈øobey his Governor, but he who thinks him≈øelf wi≈øer. The Reputation and Honour of a Prince at home, and His Re≈øpect abroad, are chief Standards of a Government. But the≈øe Pillars as much as in you lies, you have endeavour'd to ≈øhake. And unle≈øs His Maje≈øty's Honour and Right be vindicated by us, He can neither be feared at home, nor ob≈øerved abroad. Your Puni≈øhment must be as publick as your Crime. It cannot be conceived but His Maje≈øty in Ju≈øtice, in Honour, in Clemency, and in His Royal Tenderne≈øs, could have proceeded otherways than he has done. On the first of April it
was publi≈øhed that Dr. Clark was dead: On the eleventh a Mandamus was directed to you, for chu≈øing Mr. Farmer. On the ninth you pre≈øented a Petition to the Lord Pre≈øident: wherein you laid your≈øelves pro≈øtrate at His Maje≈øties Feet, repre≈øenting to him the Incapacitie of Mr. Farmer, de≈øiring the benefits of His Gracious Declaration for pre≈øerving your Rights and Properties, and be≈øeeching him to Nominate another per≈øon qualified according to your Statutes, in the Election of whom you would ≈øhew your ready obedience. So ≈øaid and ≈øo done, Gentlemen, had been very well.

But immediately after the delivery of the Petition, you not waiting His Maje≈øties An≈øwer, proceeded on April the 15th to an Election of Dr. Hough; So that by this Act, which was plainly contrary to His Maje≈øties Authority, who≈øe Mandate did certainly imply an Inhibition; you directly confronted your former promi≈øes of ready obedience, and were re≈øolved to give the King nothing but good words; when you had done this, as men of ill de≈øigns, are always in ha≈øt, for a confirmation of it, you immediately went and ≈øurprized your Vi≈øitor, and by that means per≈øwaded him to confirm Dr. Hough, that very day he received an order from the Lord Pre≈øident to the contrary.

∆≤pon this News the King was much amazed, and required an account of your Proceedings; therefore the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners i≈ø≈øued out a Citation, and after hearing the Plea: ∆≤pon mature Con≈øultation with the Learned of both Laws, judged the pretended Election of Dr. Hough to be void and null, and him to be removed, by an In≈øtrument dated the „Äà1 span left blank„Äâ which was affixed on the Gate. After this a Mandate was ≈øent on the „Äà1 span left blank„Äâ to you to Elect the Bi≈øhop of Oxon; upon which terms His Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to dispence with your di≈øobedience thitherto. But this being di≈øobeyed, His Maje≈øty in Per≈øon on the 4th of September ≈øent for you to Chri≈øt-Church, and required you immediately to Elect the Bi≈øhop of Oxon Pre≈øident. You went ≈øtrait to the Chappel, a place one would think ≈øhould have inspired more Devotion and Awe of his Sacred Maje≈øty in you; and there contemptuou≈øly Sub≈øcribed and Signed a Paper, directly thwarting his Maje≈øties Command. The ground of your di≈øobedience you pretend that you could not Elect him, whereas you could not but know by a written Mandate that lay by you, that admi≈ø≈øion would have ≈øatisfied His Maje≈øty Con≈øcience the ≈øtale Topick of Rebellion was here brought to vindicate your petulant and contumacious behaviour. You pretended that you were obliged by Oaths, and I am ≈øorry that at the ≈øame time you forgot that of Allegiance. And indeed there is not a greater ≈øign of Hypocri≈øie, than partial obedience. Had you any re≈øpect to the Father of your Country, and your Mother the Church, you would have Sacrificed your pretended Scruples, as a peace-offering to to the King. The be≈øt of us I am ≈øure, have rea≈øon to beg God and the Kings pardon. But you, as if His Maje≈øty Reigned by courte≈øie, would have a King under you, but none over you. You urged the ob≈øervance of your Statutes, of which as it hath appeared, you have not been ≈øo con≈øtant ob≈øervers, when your own humour prompts you to a di≈øpen≈øation, then you can readily embrace it; witne≈øs but that of being ≈øerved per Ma≈øculos, by which great Scandals have come to this Society by rea≈øon of Ba≈øtards.

But when the King interpo≈øed, in who≈øe power alone it is to di≈øpence with them, then you pre≈øently act according to ≈øuch methods as the≈øe. None of the≈øe pretences will ea≈øe you with wi≈øe and ≈øober men.

This was the onely oppo≈øition His Maje≈øty in his Progre≈øs received: Where-ever his Sacred Maje≈øty came, he worked a miraculous Conver≈øion, except in Oxford; and ≈øo far ≈øatisfied every one with the equity of his Proceedings, that none went away di≈øcontented from his Pre≈øence, unle≈øs it was for this rea≈øon, that they could not enjoy it any longer.

October the 20th, We came down, and upon opening our Commi≈ø≈øion, I took care to repre≈øent to you the heighnou≈øne≈øs of your Offence, and to per≈øwade you to a ≈øerious Repentance; but all in vain.

For on Saturday-morning we required you to Admit and In≈øtal the Bi≈øhop of Oxon; which all, except three, refu≈øed: In
the Afternoon Dr. Hough having been deprived, and by us commanded to depart the Colledge, came unto us without any leave, but not without great Attendance; Circum≈øtances, I think, much unbe≈øitting a man pronounc'd Expelled; and there entered a PROTESTATION against all that we had done, or hereafter ≈øhould do, as Illegal, ∆≤njust, and Null; which he delivered not in Writing, but by Word of Mouth: a thing repugnant to the nature of all Appeals: and which was wor≈øe, without the u≈øual Salvo to His Maje≈øty's Supreme Power. When he had ≈øpoken it, there followed ≈øuch a Tumultuous, Seditious, and In≈øolent HUM, which if you your ≈øelves had not applauded, or at least con≈øented to it, was impo≈ø≈øible but that you would have di≈øcovered ≈øome of tho≈øe Mutineers. However, ≈øince his Carriage and Language gave occa≈øion to it, 'twas thought fit that he onely ≈øhould be obnoxious; and accordingly he was bound over.

On Tue≈øday we our ≈øelves cau≈øed the Bi≈øhop of Oxon to be In≈øtalled by his Proxy; after which we propo≈øed to you, Whether, being now In≈øtalled, you would ≈øubmit to him licitis & hone≈øtis? To which you gave an An≈øwer under your Hands in the Affirmative. You then al≈øo de≈øired of us to repre≈øent your Ca≈øe favourably to His Maje≈øty, giving all a≈ø≈øurance of your Loyalty and Obedience. But this a≈ø≈øurance of Submi≈ø≈øion la≈øted not long; for on Thur≈øday, being required of us to Sub≈øcribe ≈øuch a Submi≈ø≈øion to His Maje≈øty as we thought agreeable to your Duty, you required time to con≈øult of it; and after deliberation, Sign'd ≈øuch a Paper, which ≈øeem'd rather to be a Prote≈øtation against your former Submi≈ø≈øion, than an Acknowledgment of your Crime. ∆≤pon this we might ju≈øtly then have proceeded to an Expul≈øion: but we thought fit, in compa≈ø≈øion to you, to take a Journey to London, and acquaint His Maje≈øty with your Di≈øobedience and ungrateful Behaviour. His Maje≈øty was extreamly amaz'd that His Clemency ≈øhould be de≈øpi≈øed; but yet, to your comforts be it ≈øpoken, His Patience and Goodne≈øs extends as far as your Provocations can: But if you ≈øtill per≈øist in your Ob≈øtinacie, tho≈øe that are too Tall to Stand, and too Stuborn to Bend, de≈øerve to be Broken. And now, I think, I have ≈øaid enough to let you know, that the Figg-leaves you have ≈øo artificially ≈øtiched together, are not ≈øufficient to cover your Nakedne≈øs. I wi≈øh to God you had the ≈øame tenderne≈øs for your Concern, as His Maje≈øty's Commi≈ø≈øioners have for you. But if you ≈øtill per≈øist to oppo≈øe the Royal Power of the King, we, who are come to vindicate the Right and Honour of His Maje≈øty, re≈øolved to di≈øcharge our Con≈øciences and Duties to God and the King, without any re≈øpect of Popularity; that's but the Paradi≈øe of Fools, and Scorn of Wi≈øe Men: and therefore, as for us, we have no more regard to Peoples di≈ølike, than what they dream: By rea≈øon therefore of your late Hypocritical Submi≈ø≈øion, the Commi≈ø≈øioners has thought fit, upon mature con≈øideration, to draw up an In≈øtrument which ≈øhall be read to you, to which, if you ≈øhall immediately ≈øub≈øcribe, before you leave the Room, we ≈øhall leave you to His Maje≈øty's Pardon: And this we expect from you all, except Mr. Tho. Smith and Mr. Charnock, with who≈øe Behaviour the King is ≈øo well ≈øatisfied; that he expects no more from them.

p.hi: Then all the Fellows being called in, their Lord≈øhips tendred a Form of Submi≈ø≈øion to them to be Signed. Which take as followeth:

div.head: To the KING's Mo≈øt Excellent MAJESTY.
The Humble Petition and Submi≈ø≈øion of the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge in the Univer≈øity of Oxon, who≈øe Names are Sub≈øcribed.
div.p: WE Your Maie≈øties mo≈øt humble Petitioners, have a deep ≈øen≈øe of being ju≈øtly fallen under Your Maje≈øties Di≈øplea≈øure, for our di≈øobedience and contempt to Your Maje≈øty; and to the Authority of Your Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners and Vi≈øitors; We do in all humility pro≈øtrate our ≈øelves as Your Maje≈øties Fear, humbly begging Your Pardon for our ≈øaid offences, and promi≈øing that we will for the future behave our ≈øelves more dutifully, and as a Te≈øtimony thereof, we do acknowledge the Authority of Your Maje≈øties ≈øaid Vi≈øitors, and the Ju≈øtice of their Proceedings; And we do declare our entire Submi≈ø≈øion to the Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon as our Pre≈øident.
To which Paperall (except Dr. Thomas Smyth, and Mr. Chernock) refu≈øed to Sub≈øcribe.
Dr. Aldworth as Vice Pre≈øident was fir≈øt call'd in to ≈øign the Paper which had been read to all the Fellows.

sp.speaker: Vice Pre≈øident.
sp.p: My Lords, we de≈øire time to con≈øider of it, and to give our an≈øwer in Writing.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: No, You mu≈øt every one Sign, or refu≈øe as you are called.

sp.speaker: Bar. Jennor.
sp.p: There is no an≈øwer to be given, but ay, or no.

div.p: They all moved again for time, but 'twas refu≈øed.

sp.speaker: V. Pr.
sp.p: My Lords, this is the fir≈øt time of my appearance before your Lord≈øhips ≈øince your ≈øitting here, and therefore I pray to be heard.

My Lords, I am as ready to comply with the King's plea≈øure, as any man living; neither do I know, that we have ever in this place been di≈øobedient to the King, where it was in our power to obey His Commands: Our Founder in the fir≈øt clau≈øe of the Oath we take at this Election, has provided; that no one ≈øhall be Pre≈øident of His Colledge, but who was bred in it, or in the Colledge where he him≈øelf was bred. Now for us who have Elected Dr. Hough, a Per≈øon qualified according to our Statutes, who has been In≈øtalled, Sworn, Confirm'd, and Approv'd of in all the ways and manner pre≈øcribed in the Statutes for us. My Lords, to accept and admit of a Stranger, and a Forreigner in his place, is to the be≈øt of my under≈øtanding, a giving up the Rights of the Colledge to other u≈øes then the Founder de≈øigned it. Here he was interrupted.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Your Statutes are over-rul'd by the King's Authority.

sp.speaker: V. Pr.
sp.p: My Lords, Your Lord≈øhips ≈øit here as the Vi≈øitors; which implies, there are certain Laws and Statutes we are bid to ob≈øerve, and by which we are to be govern'd; and if it ≈øhall appear to your Lord≈øhips, that we have acted conformably to the≈øe Statutes, I hope we ≈øhall neither incur the Kings di≈øplea≈øure nor your Lord≈øhips. The whole Tenour of our Statutes run, That we ≈øhould inviolably maintain our Rights, and ob≈øerve the Rules of our Founder; He has laid his Cur≈øe upon us if we vary from them. (Here he repeated the words of the Founder) Ordinamus ≈øub paen√¢ Anathematis, & indignationis Omnipotentiis Dei, &c. Item ≈øub interminatione Divini Judicis interdicimus.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Are you not to obey the King as well as the Founders Statutes?

sp.speaker: V. Pr.
sp.p: My Lord, I ever did obey the King, and ever will: Our Statutes which we are ≈øworn to ob≈øerve, are confirm'd by ≈øeveral Kings and Queens before and ≈øince the Reformation, and as we keep them, are agreeable to the Kings Laws both Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Civil, and ≈øo long as we live up to them, we obey the King.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Your Statutes were never confirm'd by His Pre≈øent Maje≈øty.

sp.speaker: Dr. John Smyth.
sp.p: My Lord, Neither have they been repealed by His Maje≈øty, and what is not repeal'd is confirm'd.

div.p: Then their Lord≈øhips pre≈ø≈øing to ≈øign or refu≈øe; the Vice Pre≈øident ≈øaid,

sp.speaker: V. Pr.
sp.p: My Lords, I'll then deal plainly, in regard to my Oath and the Statutes, to the right of all our Succe≈ø≈øours and of Dr. Hough, whom I believe to have been as fairly Elected, and as legally po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed as ever any ≈øince the Foundation of the Colledge: I cannot ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as Pre≈øident. So he was ordered to withdraw.

div.p: Then the ≈øame que≈øtion was put to all the other Fellows ≈øingly, who all refu≈øed to ≈øign the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, (except Dr. Thomas Smyth and Mr. Chernock, who were not pre≈øt for the Rea≈øons above.)
Mr. Thomp≈øon being called in to ≈øign the Paper, ≈øaid

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomp≈øon.
sp.p: My Lords, I have been always obedient to His Maje≈øties Commands, I was not concerned in the Election of Dr. Hough; I voted for Mr. Farmer, and am ready to ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon.

sp.speaker: Bi≈øh. Ch.
sp.p: Did you not put your hand to this Petition? Is not this your hand ‚ÄîRead the Petition‚ÄîIt was Read‚Äî In which the Fellows de≈øired His Maje≈øty, to nominate any qualified Per≈øon, and to retract His Mandate granted for Mr. Farmer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomp≈øon.
sp.p: My Lord, I conceive the Petition not to be di≈øobedient. We had not yet receiv'd the Mandate, as ≈øoon as it came, I humbled my ≈øelf.

sp.speaker: Bar. Jen.
sp.p: Then why can't you humble your ≈øelf again; is there any hurt in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomp≈øon.
sp.p: This Paper requires me to own my di≈øobedience to His Maje≈øty; I am not con≈øcious of any, and therefore I cannot Sub≈øcribe.

div.p: After a ≈øhort time, all who refu≈øed to ≈øign the Submi≈ø≈øion were called in, and by Sentence of their Lord≈øhips, expell'd the Colledge for Contempt, &c. (except as before)‚ÄîAfter Sentence, all that were expell'd ≈øpoke to this Effect: ‚ÄîMy Lords, we pro≈øe≈øs all Duty to the King and Re≈øpect to your Lord≈øhips, but mu≈øt beg leave to declare; That we think our ≈øelves injur'd in your Lord≈øhips proceedings, and therefore prote≈øt again≈øt them, and ≈øhall u≈øe all ju≈øt and legal ways of being Relieved‚Äî
After a ≈øhort time, an In≈øtrument was fix't on the Colledge-Gates, in the≈øe words.

div.head: By his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes, &c. particularly Authorized and Impowered to Vi≈øit St. Mary Magdalen Colledge in the ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxon.
div.p: WHereas in our Vi≈øitation of the ≈øaid Colledge, it appeareth unto us, that Doctor Charles Aldworth, Dr. Alexander Pud≈øey, Dr. John Smith, Dr. Tho. Bailey, Dr. Tho. Stafford, Ma≈øter Robert Almond, Mr. Manwaring Hamond, Mr. John Rogers, Mr. Richard Strickland, Mr. Henry Dob≈øon, Mr. James Bailey, Mr. John Davies, Mr. Francis Bag≈øhaw, Mr. James Fayrer, Mr. Jo≈øeph Harwar, Mr. Tho. Bateman, Mr. George Hunt, Mr. William Cradock, Mr. John Gillman, Mr. Geo. Fulham, Mr. Charles Penny≈øton, Mr. Robert Hyde, Mr. John Yerbury, Mr. Robert Holden, and Mr. Stephen Wilks, Fellows of the ≈øame Colledge, have been ≈øeverally guilty of Di≈øobedience to his Maje≈øty's Commands, and ob≈øtinately contemn'd his Royal Authority, and do ≈øtill per≈øi≈øt in the ≈øame: We have thought fit, upon mature con≈øideration thereof, to Declare, Pronounce, and Decree, That the ≈øaid Dr. Charles Aldworth, &c. and every of them, be Deprived and Expelled from their re≈øpective Fellow≈øhips: And we do by this our Sentence and Decree, Deprive and Expel them and their ≈øaid ≈øeveral and re≈øpective Fellow≈øhips.

div.head: WHITE-HALL, Decemb. 10.
div.p:
HIS Maje≈øty's Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes, and for Vi≈øiting all Cathedral and Collegiate Churches and Colledges, &c. met this day; and taking into their con≈øideration all that had pa≈ø≈øed in the bu≈øine≈øs of St. Mary Magdalen Colledge in Oxford, and the contemptuous and di≈øobedient Behaviour of Dr. John Hough, and ≈øeveral of the Fellows of that Colledge, throughout the whole Proceeding, their Lord≈øhips Declared, Decreed, and Pronounced, That Dr. Hough,
Dr. Carles Aldworth, Dr. Henry Fairfax, Dr. Alexander Pud≈øey, Dr. John Smith, Dr. Thomas Bailey, Dr. Thomas Stafford, Mr. Robert Almond, Mr. Manwaring Hamond, Mr. John Rogers, Mr. Richard Strickland, Mr. Henry Dob≈øon, Mr. James Bailey, Mr. John Davies, Mr. Francis Bag≈øhaw, Mr. James Fayrer, Mr. Jo≈øeph Harwar, Mr. Thomas Bateman, Mr. George Hunt, Mr. William Cradock, Mr. John Gillman, Mr. George Fulham, Mr. Charles Penny≈øton, Mr. Robert Hyde, Mr. Edward Yerbury, Mr. Henry Holden, and Mr. Stephen Wilks, ≈øhould be uncapable of Receiving, or being Admitted to any Eccle≈øia≈øtical Dignity, Benefice, or Promotion: And ≈øuch of them who are not yet in holy Orders, were adjudged uncapable of Receiving or being Admitted into the ≈øame. All Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and other Eccle≈øia≈øtical Officers and Mini≈øters within the Kingdom of England, being required to take notice of the ≈øaid Sentence and Decree, and to yield Obedience thereunto.

THE 17th of January, 1687. being the day that the Thirty Demies of Magdalen Colledge were, by Summons from the Bi≈øhop of Oxon, the new Pre≈øident, commanded to appear before him; and none appearing, Mr. Chernock, the new Vice-Pre≈øident, called for the Buttery-Book, and ≈øtruck out the Names of Mr. Holt, Mr. Adams Senior, Mr. Ve≈øcy, and Mr. Brabourn, Ma≈øters of Art; Mr. Hyde, Mr. Woodward, Mr. Fulham, Mr. Watkins, Mr. Stacy, Mr. Sherwin, and Mr. Kenton, Batchelors of Art; Mr. Cro≈øs, Mr. Bu≈øh, and Mr. Wells, Under-Graduates: Which Fourteen were then re≈øident in the Univer≈øity, and Three more, who e≈øcaped Expul≈øion at that time.
